story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Analysis: The prime minister&nbspis stuck with an unpopular policy done on the cheap by her predecessors, says Benjamin&nbspKentish. But she cannot let it distract her from securing a deal on BrexitClick to followIndy PoliticsThe row over universal credit could not have come at a worse time for&nbspTheresa May. With most of Whitehall’s resources and almost all of Downing Street’s political capital focused on Brexit, No 10 is now also having to stave off growing backbench unrest about the government’s flagship welfare policy.The introduction of the new system has been dogged by delays and warnings about the impact on struggling families. Ministers have already made a series of changes and no one doubts that more will be needed. Esther McVey, the work and pensions secretary, told the Commons yesterday that the government “will make sure we get this benefit right”. People may ask why, six years after the change was approved by parliament, it has not done so already.Tory backbenchers are increasingly concerned about the policy and the impact it will have on their constituents. This is not a minor reform – the switch to universal credit will affect eight million working-age people. MPs are already being bombarded with tales of people forced into debt, destitution and, according to one Labour MP, prostitution&nbspas they are transferred to the new system.Labour fails to force government to release universal credit papersPolitically, too, the fiasco is damaging for the Conservatives. If the next election is not until 2022, it is issues of public services and welfare that could prove pivotal, especially universal credit, which directly affects more than one in eight voters. The public bought into the idea of belt-tightening when it was needed to reduce the deficit. With the economy growing and Ms May having heralded the end of austerity, that argument no longer holds.The tales of hardship that accompany every debate on universal credit will trouble Tories who fear once again being seen as the nasty party, and fuel perceptions that Conservative modernisers worked so hard to dispel.The disastrous implementation of the policy also spectacularly undermines what will inevitably be one of the Tories’ main electoral arguments: that they are the party of competence and efficient management. The result is a policy pushed through on the cheap, without the proper funding and thought needed to adequately implement such a drastic change to the welfare system. Philip Hammond is likely to use this month’s Budget to plough further money into the policy, but it is unlikely to be enough to solve its&nbspmultiple problems.The frustration for Ms May is that the fiasco causing her such a headache is not of her own making. Universal credit was introduced long before she became prime minister. It is hard to believe that, if she could, Ms May would not quietly scrap it and be done. But that would be a huge admission of failure on the part of her government and a major victory for Labour. &nbspUniversal credit is the greatest blunder by a British government yetInstead we can expect further delays as ministers scramble to amend the flawed policy while also staving off the prospect of a parliamentary defeat. With Tory backbenchers warning that almost 30 of them are prepared to vote against the government on the issue, any significant votes on universal credit&nbspare likely to be pushed back until next summer at the earliest. story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsSales volumes declined by 0.8 per cent in the month, worse than the 0.4 per cent anticipated by City of London analystsClick to followThe IndependentThere was no growth from non-food store sales in SeptemberThere was a bigger than expected fall in UK retail sales in September, official figures showed on Thursday.The Office for National Statistics reported that sales volumes declined by 0.8 per cent in the month, worse than the 0.4 per cent anticipated by City of London analysts.What is really going wrong with the UK retail sector?This followed strong activity from shoppers in the July and August heatwave, when Britons splashed out on food and drink.In September food sales were down sharply. There was a decline in non-store retailing activity and no growth from non-food stores.Over the three months to September sales volumes were still up 1.2 per cent, although this was down from the 1.9 per cent rate in the three months to July.Retail sales account for around 30 per cent of total consumer spending and are seen as a bellwether of the direction of the overall economy.“Some easing back in retail sales was always to be expected in September given the overall strength in August and July,” said&nbspHoward Archer of the EY Item Club.He added that third-quarter growth “buoys belief that consumer spending&nbspmade an appreciable contribution as GDP growth likely improved to at least 0.6 per cent&nbspquarter-on-quarter in the third quarter.”The ONS estimates that GDP growth was 0.4 per cent in the second quarter of 2018.But other analysts were less optimistic.“It looks like consumer spending – along with the weather – peaked in early summer and has been declining ever since,” said Ben Brettell of Hargreaves Lansdown.“Where we go from here is highly uncertain. Brexit is hitting consumer confidence hard, but on the plus side wage growth has hit a decade high while inflation is falling. story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the options‘Arab governments have been given free rein to continue silencing the media at an increasing rate’Click to followThe IndependentAn ominous warning that Middle Eastern governments “have been given free rein to continue silencing the media” has been published by The Washington Post two weeks after the disappearance of its author, Saudi dissident journalist Jamal&nbspKhashoggi.Mr Khashoggi’s column was published on Wednesday, a little over a fortnight since he was last seen, crossing the threshold of the Saudi consulate in Istanbul.It was released hours after a gruesome account in Turkey’s pro-government&nbspYeni&nbspSafak&nbspnewspaper alleged Saudi officials had cut off Mr Khashoggi’s fingers and then decapitated him inside the consulate while his fiancee waited outside.Jamal Khashoggi: ‘What the Arab world needs most is free expression’The Saudi government, including its crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, has denied all involvement in the face of international outrage at his disappearance.In an introduction to the column, the&nbspPost’s global opinions editor, Karen Attiah, said she received the essay from Mr Khashoggi’s translator and assistant the day after he was reported missing.In the op-ed, titled “Jamal Khashoggi: What the Arab world needs most is free expression”,&nbspMr Khashoggi recounted the imprisonment of a prominent writer who spoke against the Saudi establishment, and cited an incident in which the Egyptian government seized control of a newspaper.&nbsp“These actions no longer carry the consequence of a backlash from the international community. Instead, these actions may trigger condemnation quickly followed by silence,” he wrote.&nbsp“As a result, Arab governments have been given free rein to continue silencing the media at an increasing rate.”&nbspPompeo arrives in Saudi Arabia to discuss Jamal Khashoggi disappearanceIn the column, Mr Khashoggi, a Saudi citizen who went into self-imposed exile in the US following&nbspthe rise of the crown prince, also discussed the practice of Middle Eastern governments blocking internet access to keep tight control of the information their citizens can see.&nbsp“The Arab world is facing its own version of an Iron Curtain, imposed not by external actors but through domestic forces vying for power,” he wrote.&nbspSuspects in Khashoggi case ‘tied to Saudi Crown Prince or his circle’Turkey seeks to reshape ties with US and Saudi over missing journalistIMF chief pulls out of Saudi conference amid missing journalist stormInside the kingdom, Saudis rattled by handling of Jamal Khashoggi caseHe praised the Post for translating many of his columns into Arabic and said it was important for Middle Easterners to be able to read about democracy in the West.He also said it was critical&nbspArab voices had&nbspa platform from which to be heard.&nbsp“We suffer from poverty, mismanagement and poor education,” Mr Khashoggi wrote. “Through the creation of an independent international forum, isolated from the influence of nationalist governments spreading hate through propaganda, ordinary people in the Arab world would be able to address the structural problems their societies face.”Mr Khashoggi&nbspstarted writing for the&nbspPost’s&nbspopinion section in September 2017 and his columns often criticised the prince and direction the Saudi kingdom was taking.&nbspCreated with Sketch.World news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Honduran migrants heading in a caravan to the United States, leave Guatemala City. story: They threaten to try to amend the Finance Bill enacting the October 29 Budget, to ensure Parliament gets a say if Britain wants to release more cash to Brussels after Brexit day on March 29.They fear Britain will end up paying into Brussels coffers for longer than voters or MPs want.Concern has been intensified by the fact that Philip Hammond's Budget statement will come before the UK has finalised leaving terms with the EU and the agreement has been ratified across the bloc.There are also concerns that next March's Brexit day could be postponed by extending the Article 50 deadline.Supporters of the amendment, designed by the Bow Group eurosceptic thinktank, say blocking any further payments unless Parliament explicitly approves them will force the EU to make a positive case for any future UK funds as part of a Brexit deal.                European car industry makes dramatic plea in bid to avert hard Brexit                Austria has PLAN B for hard Brexit says KurzUnless Mr Hammond himself gives the commitment, they will seek to amend the forthcoming Finance Bill to declare: Her Majesty's Government, having declared its intention to leave, and having passed legislation to leave, will pay no contribution to the European Union and its institutions after March 29th, 2019.Conservative MP Andrea Jenkyns commented: We voted to take back control, and it's always been the case that Parliament oversees the budget, not the other way around.It's absurd that there is to be a Budget before the final Brexit deal.That is effectively writing a blank cheque to the EU, and that leaves the danger that Article 50 may be extended with full funding.I have personally heard from ministers and whips that this is a possibility.Brexit news: Brexiteers are plotting to stop Mrs May extending the transition period (Image: )What I would like to propose in the Finance Bill is an amendment to say we will not pay any further monies to the EU after the 29th March 2019 without further Parliamentary approval.We need that guarantee because this is what the country voted for.Bow Group chairman Councillor Benjamin Harris-Quinney said: With or without a deal, we leave the EU on March 29th 2019.Parliament should therefore not approve any budget that allows the Exchequer to make any payment to the EU after that date, without its subsequent consent.The Chancellor should know that any attempt to sneak a Budget through that allows money to continue to flow to the EU will be opposed by Brexiteer MPs tooth and nail, and should prepare his statement accordingly.Elsewhere, Cabinet Minister Andrea Leadsom yesterday promised in the House of Commons that the UK will leave the EU on March 29, 2019, as planned.Brexit news: Theresa May is becoming increasingly isolated in Brussels and Westminster (Image: )Taking MPs' questions about how much power they will have to approve or amend any Brexit deal Theresa May brings back from Brussels, the pro-Leave Commons Leader declared: The UK will be leaving the EU Union on 29 March 2019.Once a deal with the EU has been agreed ... Parliament will have the choice to accept or reject that deal.If Parliament accepts the deal, we will introduce an EU Withdrawal Agreement Bill to implement the agreement in domestic legislation. If Parliament chooses to reject the deal, the Government will be unable to ratify the agreement.In June Parliament voted to repeal the 1972 Act under which Britain joined the bloc - a move MPs say should make Brexit unstoppable.Mrs Leadsom also promised that Parliament's February half-term holiday would go ahead - subject to the progress of business - amid speculation Downing Street is considering cancelling it to give the Commons time to pass Brexit legislation.Brexit news: Theresa May has sparked fury by considering to delay Brexit (Image: REUTERS)Downing Street meanwhile confirmed it did not plan to cancel Christmas for MPs, after claims their festive break could be postponed to deal with EU matters if a deal with Brussels cannot be struck until mid-December.Former Tory Cabinet minister John Redwood last night backed the backbench threat to vote against the Budget.He said: Many Conservative MPs are making clear to the Government that we won't support legislation seeking to prolong transition and large payments for no good reason.Extending our period under EU control would take us into another seven-year spending period and it would want even more money from us.

title: Brexit news Iain Duncan Smith Theresa May Leave EU BBC Newsnight
story: Brexit news: Mr Duncan Smith urged Mrs May to get on with it and deliver Brexit (Image: BBC)The ardent Brexiteer was appearing on the BBC&rsquos Newsnight programme when he made the comments after Theresa May&rsquos Government was branded a &ldquosh*t show by rising Tory star Johnny Mercer.Responding to Mr Mercer&rsquos extraordinary outburst, Mr Duncan Smith said: &ldquoWell it&rsquos not the language I would use, but I can understand his frustration.The former Work and Pensions Secretary continued: &ldquoWe have got to get some steel in our backbone and do something about actually negotiating something rather than just saying, &lsquowhat would you like?&rsquoHe added: &ldquoThe Government has to deliver on what the public voted for.                &lsquoWe were VERY CLEAR what Brexit meant&rsquo - Keir Starmer CONDEMNED &ldquoMost people want us just simply to get out now.&ldquoAnd the reality is: the longer we drag this on, the more we talk about being in the customs union and worrying about end dates which will never be agreed - or for that matter any idea of the European Union deciding whether or not we can leave a customs union alongside our own decision, this messy process has led us to the point where we actually look like we are asking the EU for them to give us something.&ldquoWe don&rsquot need to do that. We have a negotiation.&ldquoWe should be saying to them what our base-line is.Mr Duncan Smith was being quizzed by Newsnight present Kirsty Wark (Image: BBC)&ldquoWe are not going to be in the Customs Union - we are not going to be in the Single Market.&ldquoWe are going to take back control of our laws and our borders and our money.When presenter Kirsty Wark pressed Mr Duncan Smith on what his &ldquorecipe to get the UK through Brexit would be, he hit back in a fiery point.The MP for Chingford explained the Government had to &ldquochallenge the whole existence of the backstop, which he described as &ldquoludicrous.                Donald Tusk and EU official in MASSIVE row at a crunch Brussels summit                It's a 'sh*tshow' - Tory MP admits he wouldn't vote ConservativeTheresa May has failed to convince the EU she has anything fresh to bring to the Brexit talks (Image: )He urged Mrs May to &ldquobin the backstop and tell the EU we &ldquocan only talk when you stop trying to put a gun at our head.Ms Wark then asked Mr Duncan Smith if there was any way Theresa May was not the person for the job.Mr Duncan-Smith replied: &ldquoI absolutely want her to do the right thing.Mrs May went to Brussels this week but the bloc has not given any concessions (Image: )His remarks come as Mrs May rushed to Brussels this week for pivotal talks with the EU as she attempted to scramble together a deal.But the Prime Minister was accused by the bloc of failing to come up with anything new.As a result, German leader Angela Merkel has urged European Union members to make preparations for a no-deal Brexit after the talks failed to produce a breakthrough.

story: The Luxembourgish politician swiftly dismissed suggestions the extension of the Brexit transition deal into December 2021 means the UK remains a member of the EU.Mr Bettel also warned Theresa May times is running out on striking a deal, urging her to address the issues raised by the Commission in regards to the future trade arrangement with the bloc.Addressing the press ahead of a crunch meeting in Brussels, he said: On 29th March it&rsquos game over.The 29th March is the last day the United Kingdom is a member of the European Union. title: diwali 2018 hindu festival of lights india origins
story: The festival of light sees Hindu homes decorated with candles and lights and people sharing gts - but what is the celebration all about Diwali, also known as Deepavali, is the Hindu Festival of Lights and is celebrated  every year as the spiritual victory of light over darkness.The date of the festival is calculated according to the position of the moon and the Hindu lunar calendar and is usually in October or November.In , Diwali will be celebrated on Wednesday, November  - and the festivities will last five days.Diwali is observed by Hindus, Sikhs and Jains around the world and is often marked by street parties, fireworks, new clothes and of course, delicious food.Traditional earthen diyas or candles are lit, and houses are decorated with colourful rangoli artworks – patterns created on the floor using coloured rice or powder.During the festival, families and friends share sweets and gts and there is also a strong belief in giving to those in need.It is also traditional for homes to be cleaned and new clothes to be worn.Indian sweets which come in a range of colours and flavours are also eaten during the celebrations, as well as ious rich savoury and sweet dishes.The five-day festival, which coincides with Hindu New Year, is seen to be one of the most signicant in the Indian culture.Many people celebrate the legend of Hindu God Rama and his we Sitas ing to their kingdom in northern India after being exiled following the defeat of demon king Ravanna.The word itself means series of lights and during the festival houses and shops are decorated with candles and lights.This is meant to represent light over darkness and the Hindu belief that good will always triumph over evil.For many Indians, Diwali honours Lakshmi, the goddess of wealth and people will start the new business year at Diwali and some will say prayers to the goddess for a prosperous year ahead. Indian sweetmeats - known as mithai - take centre stage during the festivities.They are nibbled throughout the day as a sweet snack, and are later served alongside a savoury dinner or snacks like samosas.Barfi - or coconut fudge - title: brexit is worst defeat since 1066
story: As negotiations flicker to a halt, it seems Brexit actually means abject surrender, taking orders from Brussels and standing mute as the Council of Europe assumes control of our economy. We risk being sold down the river.Barring a last-minute revolt by Tory Brexiteers, Brussels has won and we have lost. The world’s sixth-largest economy will not just be worse off outside the EU, but reduced to a powerless political pawn on its margins — and paying for it.Sniggering can be heard across the capitals of Europe, with France guffawing loudest. The British Lion is a toothless kitten and we are the laughing stock of Europe.Unless stopped by her Cabinet, her MPs or by Parliament itself, this Prime Minister seems to be leading us to the greatest defeat since the Norman Conquest in , the last time we capitulated to a foreign power.The ransom demanded for our degrading humiliation — £BILLION of taxpayers’ money — is merely a down payment. The botched Chequers deal will bind this country in subordination to Europe.Forget about becoming a sovereign, free-trading nation. We will accept EU rules indefinitely while having no say at all in their terms or conditions. In effect, our economy will be run by Brussels, not by our democratically elected government.For an example of missed opportunities and failed leadership, this beats even last year’s election disaster, which wasted the first Tory majority for  years and put Marxist Labour within grasp of power.Worse, it now seems the PM’s apparent last-ditch capitulation was stitched up months ago behind closed doors after a dodgy threat by car giants to leave the UK.Now the Tory party is in uproar, with cries for a leadership contest. Downing Street is stupidly threatening a snap election. Nobody buys that except Jeremy Corbyn, who is licking his lips at the scent of power. Ministers, like frogs in a pot, are sizing up whether to jump or stew. Careers will be made or broken.At least three — and maybe six — are threatening to quit at tomorrow’s Cabinet unless Theresa blinks. Tory MPs are close to triggering a leadership fight, with sketchy plans for a quick and ruthless contest. “We have the numbers,” says one Tory MP.“If anything the mood is hardening, not softening.”Ex-Brexit secretary David Davis, the first rebel to quit Cabinet, will certainly run, infuriating Boris Johnson, who thinks it should be him. Once the gun is fired, half the Cabinet and plenty of hopefuls will join in.Everyone deserves blame, including Brexiteers who assumed the game was over after their victorious out vote and abandoned the field. Remainers are at fault for refusing to accept the will of the people — and the shortcomings of their beloved EU.But it is Downing Street, and Theresa May personally, who must take responsibility. Mrs May has dreamed of being Prime Minister since she was a child.It’s a tough job. It means leading from the front, making swt decisions and rallying the country with confidence and authority in dficult times.Instead, Mrs May’s team talk like defeatists about parliamentary “arithmetic”. How can she push through a dficult Brexit against ferocious opposition without a commanding Commons majority  But who was responsible for that parliamentary arithmetic It was Theresa May alone who decided to call an unforced election and it was she who single-handedly blew it. Her only task was to deliver the referendum mandate handed to her by .million voters. She blew that, too.People knew the risks. They did not vote for us to stay half-in, half-out or to see our sovereignty handed over to foreign powers. To govern is to decide. Mrs May made a career out of being the strong and silent type.Many of her MPs worry she is actually weak, vacillating and inarticulate.We are becoming accustomed to ruthless “wet jobs” by authoritarian tyrannies such as Russia, North Korea and the People’s Republic of China, many of them “friends” of Jeremy Corbyn.But Saudi Arabia has always revelled in public and private bloodshed. When it comes to terrorism, all roads lead back to Riyadh.A respectable MP, who does not joke about such matters, tells me the Saudi Embassy in London once had a torture chamber in the basement.I wonderit still does Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: I could see where he was going with this. After all, as we remember from school, this ancient British queen rose up against the Roman Empire, winning battles, slaughtering enemies and forcing the Romans to contemplate leaving Britain all together.“But, hang on,” I replied. “Wasn’t Boudicca eventually defeated ”Whatever the details, my friend was right. It is time for Theresa May to call on her deepest reserves of defiance and stand up to the European Union.Brussels has rejected her Brexit proposals, insulted us at the recent Salzburg summit and wants to dismember the United Kingdom by effectively annexing Northern Ireland for itself.Theresa May’s respect towards the EU has been met consistently with contempt for Britain. She has wished Brussels every success, while they wish us nothing but failure and decline. She has suggested solutions while they point out problems. And she has taken her Government to the brink by proposing a future relationship that is hated by many of her own MPs and supporters.It is time, now, to stop.Her Chequers plan already goes too far. It would tie us to European laws, over which we would have no say, and force us to accept the rulings of the European Court of Justice.It would prevent us from taking our own decisions and making our economy more competitive. And it almost certainly stops us from striking our own trade deals.Worse still,the Government persists with Chequers, we will end up with something even worse: Chequers Minus, which could mean making annual payments to Brussels, complying with more EU laws and accepting liberal immigration rules that amount to continued free movement.The longer we pretend Chequers can survive, the worse the outcome will be. As we negotiate the Withdrawal Agreement, Britain should be seeking watertight assurances about our future relationship. Without them, we will sign away a £billion orce payment without any confidence we will get a fair deal for the future.But the crisis the Prime Minister described to Parliament yesterday, and which the Cabinet will discuss today, is not about Chequers, but the so-called “backstop” — what should happen to Northern Irelandthere is no eventual agreement on the future relationship.The EU’s proposition is an outrage. If there is no deal on the future relationship, they expect Northern Ireland to remain inside the Customs Union and, in effect, the single market.That would mean, in trying to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic, we would create a hard border between Northern Ireland and Great Britain. That’s right, a border within our own country to avoid having one with another.The backstop would mean politicians in the Republic have a say over laws in Northern Ireland, while politicians in Belfast and London would have none. And it effectively breaches the Good Friday Agreement, which demands that Northern Ireland’s place in the United Kingdom is respected unless a majority of Northern Irish people vote for the reunication of Ireland.The one concession the EU seems willing to make is that the whole of the United Kingdom can remain inside the Customs Union, not just Northern Ireland.But it insists there can be no time limit, and no right for the UK to unilaterally withdraw from the backstop.In other words, we would be trapped inside the Customs Union — following laws over which we have no say, letting Brussels grant trading access to our market for other countries and leaving us unable to agree trade deals of our own — for ever.This, of course, has always been the EU’s game. They have cynically used the Northern Irish peace process to try to tie the whole of the United Kingdom to the EU’s rules and regulations. And in their naivety, our negotiators have walked straight into the trap.The PM needs to tell the EU to get stuffed. And she must go back to the drawing board. She must replace Chequers with an ambitious, Canada Plus, free trade agreement between the UK and the EU. She must insist that the Northern Irish solution lies with technology and policy that avoid checks at the border. And she must tear up the backstop.One alternative, still a compromise for Brexiteers like me, is to agree that the UK will remain inside the Customs Union for a period of up to five years while the appropriate systems are put into place.Critics will say the EU will never agree. Butthey cannot accept a trade deal consistent with their principles and which respects the integrity of their single market, we know they seek only a damaging deal for Britain, or no deal at all.Others will say the Government could not get this kind of plan through the Commons. But it stands a better chance than Chequers Minus.This was, in fact, the plan Theresa May first set out at Lancaster House in January .There, she warned against a Chequers-style deal, saying: “We do not seek to hold on to bits of membership as we leave” and “we will not have truly leftwe are not in control of our own laws”.And she warned against what the backstop demands. She insisted on creating “no new barriers to living and doing business within our own Union”, and warned against “an unlimited transitional status”, which she called a “kind of permanent political purgatory”.Instead, she sought “a comprehensive free trade agreement” and the freedom for “Britain to negotiate its own trade agreements” with other countries.In other words, she described the Canada Plus agreement that is prepared and drafted but gathering dust inside the Brexit Department.Many years ago, The Sun advised us to say “up yours, Delors” to a meddling European Commissioner. Today, the PM needs to find her inner Boudicca and say: “On your way, Barnier.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: royal wedding princess eugenie wedding soap opera
story: Too much décolletage or, God forbid, a side split and one risks what has now become known in common parlance as “doing a Raquel Welch”, who didn’t so much upstage the bride at her son’s ­wedding as eclipse her completely.And so, paralysed by the uncertainty of it all, the majority of “immediate family” wedding snaps feature the loving couple, a couple of blokes chilling in their usual suits, and two middle-aged women looking deeply uncomfortable in unforgiving taffeta and a hat that resembles an upturned lamp shade.Or, in Sarah Ferguson’s case, a titfer reminiscent of a stewardess for a s Eastern Bloc airline. Then, to keep up appearances for the family photo, Sarah had to hover nervously behind the gimlet-eyed former father-in-law who has ignored her for the past  years.But worst of all, she had to stand by and watch Prince Harry and his glossy new we sweep in and steal bride Eugenie’s thunder with news of their impending baby.A child, I might add, with the added sting of bumping the bride and her sister Beatrice even further down the line of succession.Far from feeling like a “royal wedding”, it bore all the hallmarks of a Hello! or OK!-funded celebrity shindig, or worse, an excerpt from US prime-time soap opera The Royals, starring Elizabeth Hurley.Take the, er, crowds gathered outside Windsor’s St George’s Chapel.“Who are you hoping to catch a glimpse of ” asked a TV reporter.“George Clooney,” came the cheerful reply.Someone  was hoping for David Beckham. They got neither.Both couples claimed other commitments but, given that they all took centre stage at Harry and Meghan’s nuptials and the Beckhams also made the cut for William and Kate’s big day, perhaps they felt this wasn’t A-list enough Instead, we had to make do with, among others, models Naomi Campbell, Cara ­Delevingne and Kate Moss, X Factor judges Robbie Williams and Ayda Field, and actresses Demi Moore and Liv Tyler.Some of whom uploaded gushing videos from the event and Instagram photos of their outfits with hashtag plugs for ­ious clothing brands.At a “royal” wedding  The notoriously traditional Queen Mother must be turning in her grave.There will be the modernisers within the palace walls who regard this as “progress” for a monarchy that, as they see it, must appeal to a younger generationit is to survive.But to my mind, it’s the complete opposite.The pomp, ceremony, tradition, duty and, most importantly, ­mystique of the royals is what sustains them.This wedding — between a “Princess” who performs no royal duties and her Jack of tequila trade — has shone a ­spotlight on the blindingly obvious threat that, once the dutul Queen and Prince Philip are no longer with us, the ­“modern” monarchy will continue to make ever decreasing circles until the taxpayer finally decides, “Hang on — they’re just like us” and the game will be up.With this #royalwedding where even the bride’s mother, left, Instagrammed a designer plug “for my amazing dress” that threat has just come one step closer.RITA ORA is promoting her new album Phoenix. “It’s my first global release of an album.I’m really excited to express my music to the world,” she says.But why the seemingly ­regular need to, er, express her breasts at the same time After all, Ed Sheeran has never posed in just his kecks and he’s sold  squillion records.ANGRY passengers on a flight from London Heathrow to Istanbul intervened to stop Home Office officials from deporting Somalian Yaqub Ahmed.“I know he’s scared,” protested one, before leading a chant of: “Take him off the plane, take him off the plane.”Though probably not as scared as the -year-old girl who was gang-raped in London by Ahmed and two of his equally unsavoury friends – the crime for which he was being deported before these witless do-gooders stepped in.Pitully, the officials capitulated and Ahmed is still in this country awaiting our next move.Meanwhile, as some of the passengers virtue-signalled their liberal credentials by posting footage of the showdown, perhaps they could now be identied and charged with obstructing the course of justice Or, at the very least, be asked to welcome the delightful Mr Ahmed into their own homes until such time as his removal can be rearranged Let’s seetheir liberalism extends to putting their own teenage daughters at risk.PIZZAS and pies must shrink to tackle obesity, claim new official guidelines from Public Health England.Sigh. Amazing, isn’t it, how millions of people manage to stay slim by eating healthily and doing moderate exercise while advocating the same mindset to their children Radical, I know, buta pizza is large, how about sharing it Or perhaps not buying it at all Or is a slice of personal responsibility too hard to swallow CHANNING Tatum and Jessie J are dating.We know this because they’ve been spotted ­laughing together at a mini-golf course.Ah yes, those heady, early months of dating when you’re presenting the best side of yourself and pretending you just love doing kooky stuff like ­hitting a ball into the clown’s mouth or paddling in pointless circles around the local ­boating lake.Then the eager-to-please phase passes and, before you know it, you’re watching ­separate TV shows in dferent parts of the house. And what a blessed relief it is too.QUESTION Time is holding a series of auditions for potential David Dimbleby replacements such as Kirsty Wark, Emily Maitlis, Nick Robinson and Julie Etchingham.They are each chairing a  of politicians and journalists in front of a live audience – the only dference being the programmes won’t be broadcast.Meaning that every last one will be far better than the real thing where, with a few notable exceptions, participants now sanitise their every utterance for fear of being publicly mauled by the kangaroo court of social media.GWYNETH  Paltrow and her new husband Brad Falchuk now refer to them- selves as “The Faltrows”. Let’s just hope that German ice skater Paul Boll doesn’t take a shine to Jane Horrocks.THE SUN has ­partnered with the Movember Foundation to help raise funds and awareness for men’s health issues by ­encouraging people to grow a sponsored ­moustache.Count me in.Post-menopause, this is the look I’m aiming for.AN “invisible” super-yacht has been invented for ­billionaires who value their privacy.Costing £million, it is coated in mirrored glass which, according to the designer, makes it “disappear between water and sea”.Er, doesn’t that mean other vessels will smash into it Still, at least it will sink ­privately. KATE SILVERTON asks her six-year-old daughter each day: “How did you fail today ”The Strictly contestant, who advocates taking kids outside their comfort zone by trying boxing or climbing, adds: “You are not ­trying hard enoughyou haven’t failed.”Perhaps give skying a miss though, eh ANT McPARTLIN and estranged we Lisa ­Armstrong received their decree nisi yesterday.Meaning that in six weeks’ time, the petitioner can apply for the decree absolute as long as everyone is agreed on the ision of cash and assets.In other words – as anyone who’s orced will know – this is when the arguments really begin.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: An official inquiry condemned him and his regime for a hideous culture of sex harassment and intimidation going back years. title: 180000 brits are owed 5000 each after having their benefits underpaid by bungling officials
story: The Government will pay an average of £, to , disabled or ill claimants who were short-changed for years.The Department for Work and Pensions announced it faces a bill of nearly £billion for the blunder - three times as much as previously thought.It is the latest embarrassment for the department which is already under fire over the rollout of Universal Credit.Earlier this year, the DWP admitted it had underpaid thousands of claimants of Employment Support Allowance, which is intended for those too ill to work.Officials claimed , people were affected, with a total estimated cost of £million.But today they published an update which shows the numbers involved are much higher than previously thought.A total of , claimants are owed an average of £, each, with some due to be paid as much as £,.The overall bill to the taxpayer will be £million, most of which will be paid out over the next two years.Just  per cent of those affected have been paid the benefits they are owed.Civil servants are in the process of contacting the other , claimants and hope to be finished by next April.They are prioritising the most serious cases including those of people who are now terminally ill.Labour MP Neil Coyle blasted: Another criminal let-down of thousands of disabled people by a callous Government and a chaotic DWP.A spokesman for the DWP said: “Anyone affected by this historic error will receive all of the money they are entitled to.That is why we have created a dedicated team of over  staff to examine cases, and have paid back around £million so far.“We have worked with charities and other disability organisations to make sure that we are providing the right support to all affected claimants and are hiring and allocating more staff to do that.”

title: theresa may needs to say no
story: The proposal to keep us shackled to the EU for another year beyond the transition period is an outrageous non-starter.We have compromised far too much. Mrs May cannot go further than her over-generous Chequers offer. This latest ruse is an insult she must repel.We would be in the farcical position of voting to Leave in June , yet still bound by Brussels rules until December  at the earliest. Which means continuing free movement, another £billion of public money tipped into EU coffers and no say over any of it.The Irish border problem is an overhyped stunt. The EU admits it would never build one even in a No Deal. Nor would we. Yet we are told we must buckle to their every whim to “avoid” such a border. Who would build it Mrs May is playing with fire even ­considering this new surrender.Unless she can give a date when we will leave the EU and ALL its major institutions she cannot claim to have fulfilled the referendum vote.When, PM, will we take back control FOR two years Leavers have had to suffer political has-beens being given s to bellyache about Brexit.Tony Blair, Nick Clegg and Michael Heseltine yesterday crossed the line into outright treachery.How  to describe their sickening appeal to the EU to frustrate exit negotiations long enough to buy Remainers time for a second referendum   A plea orchestrated to coincide with Mrs May’s crucial Brussels summit.Instead of backing Britain, and our historic decision, these meddling losers conspire with the EU to undermine our interests. The hypocrisy, arrogance and blinkered ­stupidity are jaw-dropping.Blair’s cabal claim to be motivated by “our support for democracy”.  It is a lie.A second referendum does not serve democracy. How could it  It is a naked attempt to reverse the biggest mandate in our history before it is enacted. title: drink drive ex on the beach star 20 stuns cops by claiming her surgically enhanced lips were too big to blow into the breathalyser
story: Sozzled Scarlett Harrison, , was pulled over by traffic cops after downing pink gins in Manchester city centre and was taken to a police station.But when she was asked to give a breath sample, she claimed her surgically enhanced lips were too big and made it dficult to get her mouth around the tube.The beautician was later charged with failing to provide a breath sample after refusing four times to blow into the intoximeter machine.She initially denied the charge - insisting she was unable to give a breath sample for medical reasons.But on the first day of her trial at Manchester Magistrates Court she changed her plea and has since been banned from the roads for  months.The court heard how Harrison, from leafy Bramhall in Cheshire, was pulled over in her Mini One on June  after rowing with a pal.Cops smelt booze on her breath so she was taken to the police station to be tested.Prosecutor Neil White said: They askedshe had any medical conditions or health conditions that could stop her doing so and she said no, just my lips.This has since been claried and she was not able to give enough medical evidence, and it was as simple as that.Her lawyer, Matthew Wallace, explained the reality star has just ed from working abroad in Ibiza and is about to start a job in a restaurant.Sentencing, Manchester JPs told her: “We have discussed things carefully and I have listened to everything that’s been said.This is a serious offence you have been charged with, drink drivers cause danger to the public.”Harrison was also fined £ plus £ in court costs and was offered a place on a drink driver rehabilitation course.Harrison appeared on this summers series of Ex On The Beach - where she had a turbulent relationship with former partner Nick.

title: mccauley cox woman run over newport nightclub
story: Cox mounted a kerb and drove over two female victims, leaving them with serious injuries.CCTV used in the trial shows Coxs car approaching a crowd of pedestrians outside the Courtyard nightclub, as a group begin fighting in the early hours of April .The car can then be seen clipping one of the pedestrians before darting forwards and swerving towards a group of people.Cox then ran over victims Sophie Poole and Emma Nicholls - before reversing back over them.Revellers then start to kick his Ford C-Max people carrier and confront him at either side of the vehicle.Police found the car later that day engulfed in flames. Cox said he decided to park it up after its engine began to smoke, and denied intentionally torching it.On Wednesday, Cox told his trial he accidentally ran over victims Miss Poole and Miss Nicholls after becoming frightened by revellers threatening to batter him in his vehicle, which he claims he had driven near the crowd of people to break up the fight.But prosecutor James Wilson accused Cox of using his vehicle to deliberately run over a man who was trading blows with his friend, only to miss and repeatedly run over the two young women, aged in their early twenties, who were sitting on a kerb.Mr Wilson said: Today you say you wanted to try and break up the fight.But you know full well you werent breaking a fight up. You were using the car as a weapon.You know full well the reason you went for that man is because he was confronting a friend of yours.You deliberately drove that car at that man with intent to cause him very serious harm.And you are responsible for those girls injuries because of your anger and annoyance at that man who was confronting your friend.Cox denied trying to hit the man, who has not been identied, and also denied knowing he had run over Miss Poole and Miss Nicholls, despite driving over and reversing over their bodies twice and subsequently having his car attacked by witnesses.It comes after Benjamin Thomas and Callum Banton, both , were pleaded guilty to affray and were jailed.Cox previously told the court: It felt like I hit something and I went into the air and came down and I was stuck.It was like it was stuck on top of something and I couldnt move forward.I werent paying attention properly. I wasnt thinking. I thought I hit a bin or a bollard.I only realised Id hit someone when I was arrested.He said he had been scared by people threatening him through his side window and had tried to flee by driving around the crowd of people and mounting the pavement.But Mr Wilson pointed out the pavement had been occupied by several pedestrians at the time, including victims Miss Poole and Miss Nicholls.Newport Crown Court had previously heard the university friends suffered really serious injuries after being repeatedly run over, with Miss Poole needing specialist skin grafts and Miss Nicholls suffering a lacerated spleen.Cox, from Newport, was remanded in custody and sentencing was adjourned until Friday morning.After the verdict, Kelly Huggins of the CPS, said: McCauley Cox used his vehicle as a weapon and caused an incident which left his victims with serious injuries.The CPS showed in court that his actions in driving his car into the crowd and reversing over those injured on two occasions amounted to this serious offence.

title: factory northfleet kent covered melted metal burns
story: The victim, aged in his s, suffered multiple deep burns to his head, neck, chest, abdomen and legs in the incident at a metal refining company in Kent.Emergency services raced to the factory which melts down metal in a high-temperature furnace.He was rushed to hospital with le-threatening injuries after the melted metal poured down upon him from above and doused his body.The liquid was believed to have inflicted severe burns which melted the skin on his head, neck, back, legs and abdomen in the horric accident at .am.Colleagues at the Britannia Refined Metals site in Northfleet, Kent, immediately rushed the young man into a shower to try to cool him down and paramedics were said to have spent almost two hours treating him and rushing him to hospital by land ambulance.The victim was rushed to the Tunbridge Wells Hospital in Pembury, Kent.The factory said the employee was later transferred to the East Grinstead Hospital, a specialist burns unit in West Sussex, and that he had received emergency treatment for his injuries.His family had also been notied of the horric accident and he was now described as being in a stable condition.Britannia Refined Metals general manager, Florian von Steinkeller, said: An employee received burns following an ejection of hot metal.First aid was provided and emergency services were called. The employee was taken to Pembury Hospital and then transferred to East Grinstead Hospital. He is receiving treatment and is in a stable condition.The company has been in contact with the employee’s family to provide any help and support that may be required.The production area concerned was shut down so that a safety assessment could be made but has since been restarted.A full investigation of the incident will be carried out and further information will be provided when it is available.The plant refines metals such lead and silver and is involved in the the production of refined lead, lead alloys and silver from crude and scrap lead - but it is currently unknown which metal the victim was doused in.According to Mining Atlas, it is the largest primary lead producer within Europe, and is capable of producing more than , tonnes of lead and  tonnes of silver a year.A spokesman for Kent Police said today: “We were called to an industrial incident in Botany Road, Northfleet, at .am.“Officers attended the scene and provided support to crews from the South East Coast Ambulance Service, who conveyed a man to a local hospital.“The incident has been referred to the Health and Safety Executive.”

title: tesco worker sues colleague fart face
story: At Masood, , claims the flatulent worker did it deliberately to humiliate him because he was a Muslim.He insists in-store CCTV captured the moment of the offending fart and it amounted to bullying.But the colleague when interviewed denied parping - and Tesco dismissed an internal complaint.Mr Masood has now taken the case to an employment tribunal claiming the retail giant did not investigate properly.Legal documents state another staff member witnessed the very serious and disturbing act of a manager who broke wind in the claimants face.The two others started laughing at Mr Masood who reported it to his boss at the branch in Thornton Heath, south London.Solicitors Rahman Lowe say in papers it was unwanted conduct which had the purpose or effect of violating his dignity or creating an intimidating, hostile, degrading, humiliating and or offensive situation.They added the act created a smelly environment for him because of his race.Mr Masood says he suffered derogatory WhatsApp messages including Muslims are terrorists.The assistant, a -year Tesco veteran originally from Pakistan, was also branded a liar in front of customers.Tesco dismissed his complaint in February saying it found no evidence of race discrimination and statements were made as a joke.A hearing is due next year.

title: eu leaders beer may tough brexit admission
story: National bosses went out drinking in Brussels without the PM, before then piling more pressure on her to come up with fresh compromises to break the Irish border deadlock.Mrs May was also forced to do battle on a second front back home as she also tried to quell a fresh Brexiteers rebellion.Eurosceptic Tory MPs erupted in fury over her confirmation yesterday that she is looking at extending the  month-long transition period to keep the UK under EU rules for even longer.During a second tense day at the EU summit:The extraordinary leaders drinking session came late on Wednesday night after a dinner to discuss Brexit without Mrs May broke up early.France’s Emmanuel Macron and Germany’s Angela Merkel stunned the Belgian capital by downing beers outside a café in its famous Grand Place for two hours.The powerful duo were joined by Belgian PM Charles Michel, Luxembourg’s Xavier Bettel and Sweden’s Stefan Lofven.Instead of joining them, Mrs May was holed up alone in the Brussels ambassador’s residence after being asked to leave before the  leaders’ dinner started.Accosted by two tourists over how the Brexit negotiations were going, Ms Merkel was reported to have replied: Please, its a wonderful evening - lets not spoil it with that.With the summit – dubbed in advance a “moment of truth” for Brexit - wrapping up in disappointment without a deal again, Mrs May admitted yesterday that “here is a lot of hard work ahead”.She added: “There will be more dficult moments as we enter the final stages of the talks, but Im convinced we will secure a good deal”.Quizzed by The Sun yesterday on what had gone at home and abroad, the PM insisted: “These were always going to be tough negotiations, and they were always going to get tougher as we got to the closing stages”.The PM also went to pains to calm Tory MPs’ anger over a longer transition period, arguing it would only be for “a matter of months” and that is still only “an idea at this stage”.An extension could be useful as “a further solution” to the Irish dilemma, she also said, as living a bit longer under EU rules until a trade deal is agreed would mean the hated Irish backstop that keeps Britain within an EU custons union would then never have to kick in.But Downing Street could not rule out having to fork out billions to stay under EU rules for longer, or that it would have any time limit.Former Tory Remainers and Leavers united in anger at the proposition.Former Tory minister and moderate MP Nick Boles led the backlash, lashing out at Mrs May to claim she “is losing the confidence of colleagues of all shades of opinion.Tory MPs are now close to despair at the state of Brexit negotiations, Mr Boles added.And former Brexit Secretary David Davis dubbed it a move “in the wrong direction”, adding: This is what the EU wants, so why are we offering it Mrs Merkel and Emmanuel Macron appeared to play a game of good cop   bad cop yesterday.The German leader held fresh one-to-one talks last night with Mrs May in a bid to come up with a breakthrough on Ireland last night.Mrs Merkel appeared to have softened her hardline on Brexit yesterday.Barely enough people back her ­Chequers offer to hold their Christmas do in a Downing Street cupboard.And The Sun shares all their gloom.Mrs May admits we could extend the transition till . That the Irish backstop cannot be finite, so unless we have a watertight exit clause Brussels could lock us in its Customs Union for good.She must NEVER allow that.Yesterday the German chief economist of Deutsche Bank insisted thatwe can do deals with the US, Japan, Canada and the Commonwealth, Britain WILL thrive after Brexit and outstrip the EU.Exactly what Brussels fears.If the PM cannot secure our freedom to do all that, the game is up.The PM gleefully quoted the Berlin boss as a sign of hope, saying: “Look at what Chancellor Merkel said, ‘Where there is a will there is a way’”.But the French president, who has always been the toughest on Britain, remained defiant, insisting that there would be “no additional political compromise on the EU side”.Instead insisting the ball was still in Mrs May’s court, Mr Macron said: “Now it is for Prime Minister May to propose a solution”.EU Council President Donald Tusk declared that “not enough progress has been achieved” to call a special summit in November to sign off any deal.But he also said the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier had been instructed to keep the talks going.And a new Brussels summit will be called the moment the veteran Frenchman declares there has been a breakthrough on Ireland.Mr Tusk added: “I feel we are closer to a final solution but it is maybe more emotional impression than rational one”.It emerged last night that Mrs May’s inner sanctum Brexit Cabinet of  senior ministers had thrashed out the transition extension proposal at a tense meeting last Thursday.One senior minister told The Sun yesterday that the Cabinet would only accept a transition extension of “three to six months”, and no longer.But other members of Mrs May’s full Cabinet were “blindsided” by her transition extension title: doctor foster gp clare nettleton dating new man
story: Mum-of-two Clare Nettleton, , was suspended from her GP job after bedding two patients and leaving her husband for one of them.The medic, whose tangled love le could have been written for hit BBC drama Doctor Foster, also spied on the medical records of the family of married lover Richard Atkinson, .They wed last year after he left his we and two kids for her.But it has emerged they broke up just six months later and she is now dating keen cyclist Andy Duncan.She had already stunned villagers by sharing raunchy pictures of herself on social media after herto work at the surgery in Williton, Somerset. Shortly after, she went off work for six months with a “virus” and “exhaustion”.Last week she was back at work again and shared a pic of her smiling. title: 40st darren mcclintock boxing
story: It’s not the first time a Sun reporter has had to dodge a punch but this time it’s a heavyweight trying to land one, with his personal trainer egging him on.Luckily for me, this heavyweight is st Darren “Dibsy” McClintock, whose obesity battle hit the headlines after his trainer Mike Hind banned takeaways from serving him.And even luckier, we have both just endured a -minute bootcamp workout at Mike’s gym — and as Dibsy tips the scales at nearly four times my body weight, it means I’ve got a bit more energy left than he has, enough to dodge his last few lunges in the boxing ring.But, exhausted and covered in sweat, Dibsy still gets awarded the winner’s belt in a light-hearted ceremony.It’s another encouragement dreamed up by Mike to give Dibsy the belief that he can win his personal battle of the bulge.His story — including his admission of weighing st rather than the st widely reported last week — has brought the UK’s obesity crisis into sharp focus.We are the third fattest nation in Europe, according to the World Health Organisation, and the North East, where Dibsy lives, is one of the most obese regions in the country.He has struggled with his weight all his le, and the death of his father from cancer when Dibsy was  didn’t help his increasing reliance on comfort-eating.Numerous efforts over the years to lose weight failed and his huge bulk now has a devastating effect on his le — he is single, he can’t get a job, he has to order specially-made clothes and when he goes on holiday he has to book two plane seats.Dibsy, , finally decided to act earlier this year when a heart scare landed him in hospital for a week and a doctor delivered the stark message: “Diet or die.”Married dad-of-three Mike heard about Dibsy’s plight and offered to take him under his wing for a year.He now puts him through his paces twice a day at his Mas Body Gym, in their home town of Middlesbrough, and provides all his meals from his newly opened healthy eating diner.Dibsy was consuming an alarming , calories a day — an average man needs around , — but was burning hardly any because he was so inactive.He is now down to , a day after ditching takeaways, booze and unhealthy snacks and, thanks to his new exercise regime, is burning , a day.The results are remarkable.On day one he couldn’t walk more than a few yards without getting out of breath.I joined him for a workout on day ten as he proudly announced: “I’ve lost ½st already.”The first exercise — just a warm-up, said Mike — involved flipping a huge, kg lorry tyre.Despite his weight, Dibsy isn’t lacking in upper body strength and he made it look easy — which it isn’t.We then moved on to pushing a metal sledge theof the gym and dragging it back the other way, with Mike holding on to make it harder.Then it was on to the kg slam ball session — hurling a medicine ball into the ground with as much force as you can.Next came smashing a sledgehammer on to the lorry tyre as hard as possible, as Mike yelled at us to do it harder.The innovative bootcamp exercises are designed in part to replicate the physical exercise people might do in their daily jobs, and are perfect for Dibsy.Mike, , explained: “He is too big for conventional gym equipment, so we need to get him doing something dferent.“You work with what you’ve got and using this equipment we have devised a set of exercises that put him through it without creating too much strain on parts of his body that can’t handle it yet.“We also have a heart monitor on him all the time which gives a real-time readout of his heart rate and calorie burn rate.“The strain on his heart is something we need to keep an eye on, soit gets too much we ease off and let him rest.“We also need to make sure he doesn’t overheat, sohe is getting a bit hot we use a leaf blower to cool him down.”By then we were both shattered, but there was little time for rest as Mike moved us into the boxing ring.“Don’t hit him too hard, Dibsy,” instructed Mike. “Or not at all ”, I suggested.Thankfully, Dibsy was just about done in — the heart monitor revealed he had burnt , calories that session — and I could keep him at arm’s .Afterwards he told me how he had got so heavy.He said: “I have never been skinny but the weight started really going on in my early teens.“I have never been sporty andmy mates went to the park for a kickabout I’d just sit it out because you are embarrassedyou can’t run around with them.“My family say that my dad dying of cancer at , when I was , had a big effect, but I’m not so sure.I wouldn’t blame my weight on that, it’s down to me and no one  that I am this size.“I have been seeing doctors and dieticians for years and my weight would go up and down.I lost st at one stage but it went back on.“People do say things in the street or stare and kids call me ‘Fatty’.That obviously hurts, so I go home and comfort-eat to make me feel better, which puts more weight on, which attracts more comments. It’s a vicious cycle.“I have had girlfriends and long-term relationships and I wouldn’t say I have lost them because of the weight.“But I am single now and being this size does affect that side of your le.“I knew I had to do something after I had my recent scare. It started when I began getting out of breath.It got worse and I could hardly breathe. It was terrying and I was taken to hospital.They said my heartbeat was all over the place. Normally they said they would give me some drugs and shock my heart so the beat gets back to normal.“But they had no idea how much drugs to give me — they were scared I wouldn’t wake up.So instead they gave me beta blockers and blood thinners and basically hoped I didn’t have a heart attack.“I was in hospital for a week and a doctor came round and told me I couldn’t keep doing this.“He saidsomething didn’t change, I was heading for an early grave. To see the look on my mother’s face when he said that was heartbreaking.I have never had a doctor be so straight with me before and I decided that this time I had to do it for real.“I didn’t know Mike but I had heard of his new diner which serves healthy food so I went down with my mum and got chatting to the staff.“He got to hear about my plight and messaged me to say he could help. The next day I went to see him and he asked me about my le and what I hoped to achieve.“It was pretty emotional when we talked about what the doctor had said. My mum said she didn’t want to bury her child and we all ended up in tears.“Mike agreed to help, both with an exercise plan and a meal plan. It was intimidating going into the gym for the first time. I have been to gyms before but it has never worked for me.“But at Mike’s gym everyone is so encouraging and wants me to succeed. And the support Mike gives me away from the gym is incredible. He texts me about  times a day to check I am OK.“One evening, a couple of days into my new exercise regime, I was at home and I messaged him to say I was struggling. It was a night that I’d usually have a takeaway and I was missing it.“Without a moment’s hesitation he said, ‘I’ll see you at the gym in ten minutes’. I said, ‘But the gym is closed’. He replied, ‘I own the gym — see you there’.“We did a -minute workout and I got home exhausted and went to bed, really pleased with myself.“It’s support like that which is getting me through. I want to learn to drive and get back into work.I used to work in a chemical plant but got laid off.Since then it has been impossible to get another job because of my size.BREAKFAST: Two sausage sandwicheswith a pint of FantaMID-MORNING SNACK: Packet of crispsLUNCH: Chicken sandwich with full-fat mayonnaise, packet of crisps, a pasty and bottle of CokeDINNER: Huge plateful of chicken curry, rice, naan bread and spring rolls – plus a ham sandwich while that meal is cooking. Served with another pint of FantaSUPPER: A takeaway parmo , kebab or pizzaDRINKS: Dibsy only drank alcohol at weekends. But a typical Sunday session involved  cans of Strongbow Dark Fruit cider, ten Southern Comfort and lemonades and six JagerbombsWHAT’S A CHICKEN PARMO  Teesside delicacy, consisting of deep-fried chicken breast covered with bechamel sauce and cheese,“Work clothes don’t fit and I’m obviously a massive health and safety risk.“SoI can lose weight I will get back into work and will have less time at home, thinking about eating.”Mike takes one obese person under his wing every year to get them fit.It’s his way of giving back to the community which helped him to launch his gym with a crowdfunding appeal in .He is providing all of Dibsy’s meals free for a year, plus two training sessions a day, which would normally cost £,.As The Sun reported last week, knowing Dibsy’s big love of takeaways, Mike came up with the idea of a leaflet which he distributed to local fast food places, saying: “Do not serve this man.”Dibsy loved parmos — a local delicacy of chicken in breadcrumbs, deep fried and covered in bechamel sauce and cheese, amounting to , calories.Mike said: “His target weight is st and we will get there.His family is on board, I am on board, but most importantly Dibsy is on board.“That is vital with any addiction, admitting you have a problem and wanting to do something about it.“We will not fail.”BREAKFAST: Overnight oatswith berriesLUNCH: Omelette with green beans and broccoliDINNER: Jamaican jerk chicken and white rice or steak meatballs and pasta with broccoliDRINKS: Dibsy has ditched fizzy drinks and alcohol. He now drinks four litres of water and a protein shake each dayOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: qatar saudi blockade world cup on track
story: “Qatar could be an island when the World Cup kicks off,” tour leader Irshad Nawaz, , reveals.The Saudis are threatening to excavate a -mile long, -yards wide canal along the border, cutting off the Qatari peninsula from the mainland.And just to rub sand into the wounds, Riyadh wants to convert part of the border area into a nuclear waste burial site and military base.It’s not exactly something Qatar is boasting about in its  World Cup PR bumpf.In a region riven with rivalries, Qatar has fallen out spectacularly with neighbours including Saudi, the UAE, Bahrain and Egypt over its alleged ties to terrorism.In June , its foes started a land, sea and air blockade designed to put the gas-rich land back in its box. Saudi slammed shut Qatar’s only land border and barred state-owned Qatar Airways from its airspace.For a nation that imported much of its food and goods, it might have been calamitous. Yet little Qatar — it is smaller than Yorkshire and expecting to host .million football fans in  — has fought back.In the lunar-like landscape  miles north of capital Doha is a farming complex where black and white Holstein cows munch fodder in air-conditioned sheds. All , of them were brought in from Germany, Hungary and the US since the blockade began.It’s led to bosses at Baladna Farm being hailed as the milk sheikhs.Its marketing manager Mark Somogyi tells me: “Before the blockade at least  per cent of dairy products were from abroad. Today Qatar is practically self- sufficient in fresh milk, as little as three per cent is imported. Nobody foresaw the blockade but the country is coping very well.”So what of the vast World Cup building preparations under the blockade, which sees most goods now arriving at Hamad Port In an exclusive tour, Qatari organising committee officials were keen to show stadium preparations were on schedule.Seven futuristic arenas are rising out of the desert with one revamped, aircon blasted ground — the Khala International — already finished.For this is the World Cup where money is no object. For brimming with petro dollars, Qatar is the richest nation on Earth. At the Al Wakrah Stadium, nine miles from Doha, the seats are already going in.Modelled on traditional dhow fishing boats, the ,-capacity stadium may host games up to the quarter final stage. The pristine pitch is like a green oasis amid the construction dust where , migrant workers toil.Inside what will be a players’ dressing room, Mohammed Emaran, , is sealing plasterboard where Gareth Southgate could be giving his team-talk in four years.The labourer — who earns around £ a month for a six-day week with free lodging and food — says: “I’m happy with the work and send money home to my family in India.”Yet two migrant workers have perished during construction work at the £million arena.Anil Kumar Pasman, , from Nepal, died at Al Wakrah after being hit by a lorry in . And a -year Nepalese scaffolder fell to his death on August . He is believed to be the first reported fatality at a tournament venue since January , when British construction worker Zac Cox, , died helping refurbish the Khala International Stadium.Yet one union has claimed , people have been killed working on projects for the  tournament, a claim vehemently denied by Qatari officials. Qatar’s World Cup organising body, the Supreme Committee for Delivery and Legacy, says the Nepali scaffolder’s death is still being investigated.Project manager Thani Khala Al-Zarraa, , says of the latest tragedy: “Half an hour after I heard the news I gathered , workers at the stadium. I told them, ‘You came here to support your family, so whatever health and safety instructions we tell you is for your own good, so that you go back to your families’.“But in construction you cannot eliminate all risk. Mistakes happen.”Qatar’s £billion spend on World Cup infrastructure has eased the financial pain of the blockade for many of the .million population.Doha is currently a vast building site as new tower blocks rise and a three-line metro system is constructed. More than  greenhouses have been built in the desert amid hopes to become self-sufficient in vegetable production by .Some England fans had planned to stay in Dubai and fly in and out for the games. But direct flights have been canned under the blockade.The Middle East’s first World Cup will also have a shortfall of hotel rooms. But there are “glamping” sites in the desert while cruise ships moored in the Gulf will also provide accommodation.Yesterday Qatar was sweltering in the muggy, low Cs. But during the tournament — from November  to December  — it should be a balmy  to C. Still, a thirst-quenching beer might be out of the question.It is unclear what the rules on alcohol sales will be in a Muslim land under Sharia Law, where drinking in public is banned. Five-star hotels serve alcohol, but £ for a bottle of beer is commonplace.Budweiser told The Sun it will be an official sponsor at the Qatar World Cup — but can’t yet confirm whether it will be allowed to sell its beer at stadiums and fan festivals.Travelling supporters could also take in a camel race at the Al Shahaniya race track an hour outside Doha.After Qatar banned child jockeys in , the camels have been ridden by robots in racing silks.Another unusual sight is the desert scrapyard at Al Wukair, where around , vehicles, including cars, boats, lorries, buses, bulldozers and cranes, languish in the dust. organising committee boss Hassan al Thawadi insists: “The blockade hasn’t hindered our preparations. We had to find alternative suppliers . . .  and since then projects are still on track.”In Qatar’s beating heart, Doha’s Souk Waq market, locals have turned beating the blockade into a matter of national pride.World Cup replica hawker Ahmed Khala, , sells at least one £ le-size replica copy of the gold Fa trophy a day alongside tea mugs fashioned in the shape of niqab-clad women.Ahmed says: “Why didn’t they do a blockade before Qatar won the right to stage the World Cup  They’re jealous Qatar has the tournament.”If the blockade is still in place come , Three Lions fans will at least be guaranteed a decent cuppa.All thanks to the milk sheikhs of Arabia.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit revolt lord bridges theresa may
story: Lord Bridges has joined a growing revolt against the PM after she admitted Britain could stayed tied to the EU for another  months.It could mean abiding by all Brussels rules until December  at the earliest,  months longer than No’s current transition plan.Her concessions have enraged Remainers and Leave voters - and she now faces a make-or-break week.Lord Bridges, who served in the Brexit department between July  and June , is the latest in a growing number joining a chorus of anger.The Times reports a growing number of MPs are plotting to install David Davis as interim PM.Leave-backing Tory MPs met on Wednesday to discuss issuing letters of no confidence in the PM, the paper reports.It would need  letters to trigger a challenge.A senior Conservative source said the “current was flowing” against the Prime Minister.Meanwhile, groups representing more than  Tory Remainers had their own meeting to discuss how to block a no-deal Brexit.Nick Boles, former skills minister, accused May of trying to run down the clock and said the Conservatives were “close to despair”.May also failed to dispute claims by Ireland’s Europe minister, Helen McEntee, that she had scrapped demands for a fixed end date on her plan.The concession could mean continuing free movement of all migrants, as well as the UK having to fork out another £bn into EU coffers in fees, while having no say in any Brussels decision making.Mrs May left yesterdays dinner in Brussels after a half-hour speech, as the other  leaders enjoyed a meal of turbot cooked in beer.But Tory MPs lined up to slap down her suggestions just minutes later.Andrea Jenkyns agreed, told ITVs Peston: It’s ludicrous that it’s two years on and we haven’t got a deal. I dont think she can survive this.He speculated it could mean British taxpayers having to pay an extra £BILLION to the EU.But Tory Deputy Chairman James Cleverly played down the suggestion of extending the transition period - pointing out that it was only a proposal from the EU.

story: But for now the absence of a breakthrough will be less important to the prime minister than the absence of a breakdown.The mooted special November summit to sign a withdrawal agreement may not be in the diary, but neither is the threatened "no-deal" November summit.The big hope appears to be that an extension to the implementation period, currently due to conclude in December , might provide space for the EU to consider a UK-wide form of Irish border backstop that wouldnt require Northern Ireland to be carved off into its customs union and single market.
