story: News jaw-dropping moments in Tory MP Johnny Mercers Theresa May-bashing s**t show interviewThe Tory MP says he wouldnt have voted Toryhe wasnt a Tory MP. And it all goes downhill from thereShareByMikey SmithPolitical reporterNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAre you...sure about this Mr Mercer  "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA rising star Tory MP has branded the Government a “sh*t show” and questioned whether the party still shares his “values and ethos”.In a jaw-dropping interview for The House, Parliament’s in-house magazine , ex-British Army officer Johnny Mercer, who was only elected in  said that with hindsight his pre-MP self “wouldn’t vote”. And he attacked Theresa May and her Chequers plan.But he says he’d still like to be Defence Secretary. Mr Mercer is an Afghanistan veteran who served with  Commando, part of the Royal Artillery, before becoming an MP. Since being elected he has joined the Defence Select Committee and campaigned for veterans, including those with mental health problems and others facing prosecution for alleged crimes during the Troubles. He took his Devon seat from Labour in  and increased his majority to more than , last year. He gained notoriety when it emerged he had appeared in a shower gel advertisement, in which he was shown soaping himself while half naked.  And just this week he was on a charity edition of Channel  game show Celebrity Hunted, for which he skipped a session of the Health Select Committee. Here’s a run-down of the most…honest answers he gave in the interview.  Asked how the Johnny Mercer who left the military in  would vote now, he said: “I wouldn’t go and vote. Just being honest, I wouldn’t vote. Of course I wouldn’t, no.” . He says hes not even surethe Conservative Party reflects his views any more  “There’s no doubt about it that my set of values and ethos, I was comfortable that it was aligned with the Conservative party. I’m not as comfortable that that’s the case anymore.” . He says the current situation is a s**t show  It’s very dficult because in my DNA I’m inherently a team player. “But when you go home from here on a Thursday and go for a run across Dartmoor or whatever, and you’re stripped to your core being, I mean, yeah, you realise it’s a s**t show. . And he definitely wouldnt be a Tory MPhe were joining the party now  “If the situation was like it is now, I can safely say there would be absolutely no chance that I would try and be a Member of Parliament.” . Heres what he said when he was askedhe wanted to be part of the current government team  Well no, of course not. “I’ve been, how do I say this… when I was asked to do a certain role and made it clear that I couldn’t for one reason or another, it was made very clear to me that… I can’t, I can’t. I mean, would I want to be part of this administration  No. . And he was very specic about whats stopping him  Look, I think it’s very clear that this current administration under this Chief Whip, under this Prime Minister, there is no role for people like me. That’s fine because nothing lasts forever.  My ambition here has always been to be Defence Secretary. I’d love to be a Defence Secretary who had ten years to rip apart that department, make it work, get the offer right to our young people. We are such an amazing, proud military nation. It’s really tough to see what’s going on now. . Andhe says hes ready for a s**t fight  Going forward, at the end of the day, above everything about being an MP, above being Johnny Mercer, any of this stuff, a Conservative or whatever, I’m a patriot. “I’m not going to sit at the back of the bus and watch it head towards the edge of the clf. I’m not going to let us go down without a serious shit fight.” . And just in case you werent sure what Johnny Mercer thinks about Theresa May, heres what he said about her Chequers plan

title: former lib dem leader nick
story: NewsNick Clegg turns down Strictly Come Dancing - and says Theresa Mays dancing "was weird"It doesnt look likely that well be seeing the former Lib Dem leader strutting his stuff on TV any time soonShareCommentsByAshleigh Rainbird:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsNick Clegg revealed has revealed he turned down multiple TV show opportunities "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Former Lib Dem leader Nick Clegg reveals he turned down the chance to appear on Strictly Come Dancing .Why  “I am not dancing on the telly,” he says, stuffily. Bookies placed him favourite to follow in Ed Balls’ unco-ordinated footsteps when Nick lost his seat as MP for Sheffield Hallam in last year’s election – but he rejected the producers’ offer. And it seems just as unlikely that he’ll sign up to chow down on kangaroo testicles in the Jungle. “I have been approached by most of the shows, including Strictly,” he says. “But I have said no to all of them.” Speaking at the Pink News Awards in London, talk inevitably turned to another politician’s robotic dance moves. “It wasn’t really dancing,” Nick grimaces of Theresa May ’s awkward shape throwing. “It was weird.”Home Sec Sajid Javid was a little more complimentary, describing the PM as “Abba’s best tribute act”. Current Lib Dem leader Vince Cable quipped she was a “good sport” for the Dancing Queen moves, adding: “The fact that she can laugh at herself is to her credit. “Will she be laughing in  months’ time, who knows ”

title: paul routledge labour must put
story: NewsopinionPaul Routledge: Labour must put national interest first and help Theresa MayMirror columnist explains how his family served in the British Army - and he hasnt forgotten or never known the cataclysmic reality of Europe at war with itselfShareCommentsByPaul Routledge:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsopinionThe EU brought peace, trade, co-operation and freedom to travel where there had been enmity, rivalry and refugees "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailListen to me, just for a moment. I speak for many more of my generation than you might think. I was born in , when my country was fighting for its le against Nazi Germany and it was not clear that we would win. My father Harry was in the RAF in the Middle East. My Uncle Bob was a tail gunner in Lancasters over occupied Europe.My Uncle Jack, a Guardsman, had been invalided off the beaches at Dunkirk. Even my youthful Auntie Barbara was in the Auxiliary Territorial Service. This was total war – the Americans fighting and dying with us, for our freedom. At home it was all wartime austerity. Food and clothes were rationed. Travel was suspended. I ask you to remember because so many have either forgotten or never known the cataclysmic reality of Europe at war with itself. Remember the Blitz on London and Hull. Remember Sheffield, Coventry, Plymouth, Liverpool, Bath and York. Remember, Auschwitz, Treblinka, and the other death camps where millions of Jews were exterminated. Remember El Alamein, Tobruk, Normandy and all the battlegrounds where people gave their lives to free us from Hitler.Remember all these things and consider thoughtfully what must be done to ensure that these horrors never happen again.  The EU brought peace, trade, co-operation and freedom to travel where there had been enmity, rivalry and refugees. It is not perfect, made up of all the flaws of the people of an old, culturally and racially erse continent that historically has more often been at war than at peace. But it is nothing short of a miracle that they found the wisdom to get together in their common interest. I do not care what Theresa May brings back from Brussels, just so long as it keeps us good friends and partners with the rest of Europe. I want the peace that my father’s generation fought for to be preserved in perpetuity, for my children, and generations to come. So, when Mrs May s with her Brexit package, I look to the politicians – including those Labour MPs who have the country’s real interests at heart – to support her in the hour of the nation’s need. At this critical time it is more important to vote for a new relationship with Europe than to blindly follow the elusive dream of Jeremy Corbyn in No. The crunch is coming and it will reveal the true patriots. Because of the war I did not see my father until I was three years old. But I was lucky. At least Sgt Routledge came home. So many others didn’t.

title: ros wynne jones universal credit
story: NewsopinionRos Wynne-Jones: Universal Credit claimants want to know why no one listens to themRos Wynne-Jones has spoken to people who have written to Esther McVey about how to improve the controversial reformShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsopinionDiane Pottage, , at a stall to give people information about Universal Credit and ask them share experiences of poverty "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis week, a letter arrived on the desk of Esther McVey, Secretary of State for Work and Pensions, from the ‘APLE Collective’ – with an offer of help. “We’d like to share our ideas and experiences on how Universal Credit could be improved, so it can help people to meet their aspirations and to leave poverty,” the letter said. The APLE Collective – Addressing Poverty through Lived Experience – is not a think tank. It’s made up of real poverty experts – Universal Credit claimants from places like Stockton-on-Tees and Salford. People who want to know why, in five years since the controversial benefit was first rolled out, no one has bothered listening to them. “The Government needs to start listening to people actually on Universal Credit,” Diane Pottage, , of Stockton, one of the letter authors told me. “We keep hearing it’s working. Well, I’m sorry, it isn’t. Butyou listen to us, we can tell you how to fix it.” Tory Brexiteers blast Theresa Mays plot to keep Britain tied to the EU for longer than plannedHer solutions are: “Stop the rollout to any more places, and take time to listen to the people who are on it. Go back to fortnightly payments. Stop the five-week wait for help.” This week – after two ex-Prime Ministers attacked the benefit, and Esther McVey finally admitted “some people will be worse off” – leaked documents suggested the Government is desperately seeking solutions to stop UC becoming the new Poll Tax. Yet, the voices of claimants are still being routinely ignored. Meanwhile, the Government fought Labour tooth and nail in Parliament this week to avoid releasing its own impact assessments of how people have been affected. Ministers tampered around the edges – delaying the rollout of UC for those on existing benefits. But, of course, people in low-paid work are always becoming ‘new claimants’ as one precarious job ends and they need help while they find another one. Meanwhile, at least , people with existing claims will still be ‘migrated’ to UC during . That may seem a small numberyou don’t have children to feed. “My social safety net is gone because of Universal Credit,” another of the letter’s authors, Letitia Rose,  from West Yorkshire, said. “It’s not just the way the benefit works, it’s all the pathetic administrative errors.” The next day the Government admitted wrongly underpaying , disabled people to the tune of poundbn. Patricia, , told me she was actually working at the Jobcentre when the new benefit came in – before needing to claim UC herself when the contract ended. “It’s not better for people, it makes things worse,” she says. “I don’t think politicians would survive a week on Universal Credit, let alone a full year.” Campaigners have been inspired by events in Scotland, where claimants are being brought into the design of benefits. In April, the Scottish Social Security bill enshrined in law ideas that “social security is a human right” and that “respect for the dignity of iniduals” must be at the heart of Scottish social security. Most workers earn less than they did seven years ago when Tories came into power“This is not just about people saying how bad things are – it’s recognising they have the expertise needed to address poverty,” says Ruth Patrick, a lecturer in social policy and social work at the University of York, who works with benefit claimant group Dole Animators. People with experience of poverty are not just case studies to be wheeled out. They should have a seat at the policy-making table.” This week, the poverty experts held a string of events nationwide to mark the International Day for the Eradication of World Poverty. Diane helped run a stall at Stockton Market, urging people to share their experiences. Letitia was involved with similar events in Salford. Patricia spoke movingly at the House of Lords. And UC claimants took over @wiganpier, our Wigan Pier Project twitter account. Five years after UC started, Diane’s own story is bitterly familiar – a six-week wait for help, then a wrong payment. “I’ve been to a food bank twice before and I’m not very far from needing one again,” she says. “The system is broken. My mum and dad were both working class but they weren’t going to a food bank.” The APLE Collective has yet to hear back from McVey, but the DWP say it has received the APLE Collective’s letter and will respond “in due course”. It says that with Universal Credit people are getting into work faster and staying in work longer. A spokeswoman added that “through our ‘test and learn’ approach we continue to listen to feedback from stakeholders and claimants and make improvements to the system”. Yesterday, I dug out the DWP’s press release from the first rollout in April . “Universal Credit is nothing less than the start of a fundamental cultural sht of the welfare system,” it proclaimed. “This will revolutionise the way people experience the welfare state.” A revolution that has cost hopes, dreams, potential, and even lives.

title: tory brexiteers blast theresa mays
story: NewsTory Brexiteers blast Theresa Mays plot to keep Britain tied to the EU for longer than plannedThe Prime Minister said she could extend the -month exit transition period for "a matter of months" in a desperate bid to smash the deadlock over the Irish backstopShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  OCT News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFurious Tory Brexiteers blasted Theresa May’s plot to keep Britain tied to the EU for even longer than planned after the UK quits the bloc. The Prime Minister said she could extend the -month exit transition period for a matter of months in a desperate bid to smash the deadlock over the Irish backstop. EU chiefs welcomed the move but it triggered uproar among Leave campaigners who claimed it would delay the UKs real departure. The PM also issued a thinly-veiled warning to MPs set to vote against any deal she brings back from Brussels in the coming weeks. They should think about the importance of protecting jobs and livelihoods when they are faced with deciding on any exit deal, she said. Ministers want to deny the Commons the chance to amend the crunch motion, meaning MPs would be confronted with a take-it-or-leave-it choice between accepting any pact or crashing out without a deal. Speaking after a two-day summit in Brussels, Mrs May feared stalled talks would get even harder as teams near a deadline for sealing an agreement. She said: These were always going to be tough negotiations and they were always going to get tougher as we got to the closing stages. “There are some dficult issues we are still working through.”  This weeks crunch showdown had been earmarked for thrashing out a deal, two-and-a-half years after Britain voted to Leave. But those hopes were dashed at last months disastrous summit in Salzburg. However, Mrs May was boosted by support from fellow EU leaders in Brussels yesterday. Britain is due to leave the bloc on March . But the transition period to smooth the departure was due to run until December . Her controversial decision to take on her own backbenchers – who hold her premiership in their hands – by delaying the end date as key to winning backing from EU counterparts. But it would mean Britain pumping cash to Brussels and staying tied to bloc rules, including accepting an unlimited number of EU migrants.  European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said the “prolongation of transition period probably will happen – thats a good idea”. EU Council President Donald Tusk added: “If the UK decided an extension of the transition period would be helpful to reach a deal, I am sure the leaders would be ready to consider this positively.” But Tory MPs blasted the move.Leading Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg branded an extension a poorly thought-through idea.He told Sky News: It could be very expensive to do. It is unknown as to whether this had approval from the Cabinet when it met earlier this week. But it also doesnt solve the problem of the backstop, because the backstop would remain, as far as one can tell, at the end of this additional transition. It seems to me to be a rather poor attempt at kicking the can down the road.  MP Nick Boles, a former Remainer and close ally of Environment Secretary Michael Gove, warned: Im afraid she is losing the confidence now of colleagues of all shades of opinion, people who have been supportive of her throughout this process.They are close to despair at the state of this negotiation because there is a fear that both the Government and the European Union are trying to run out the clock, that they are trying to leave this so late that they can credibly say there is no alternative but a no-deal Brexit and most people agree that would be chaos.That is not an acceptable way for a leader of a government to behave. Mr Gove told the Commons it was vital Britain leaves the EU at the earliest possible point. International Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt said: The Prime Minister was very clear ... that she recognises the need to do things swtly, not least because that is what the public expects. That is what she deeply feels in terms of honouring the referendum result.” But EU chiefs hailed the offer, with Mr Tusk saying: “We are in a much better mood than after Salzburg. “What I feel today is that we are closer to final solutions and the deal. Its maybe more an emotional impression than a rational one but emotions matter in politics. Mr Junker predicted an extension probably will happen.

story: NewsMy girlfriends arms ached to hold our stillborn baby but I couldnt even bear to cut the cord, says dadBruce Wagstaffs partner Vicki Beckett was  weeks pregnant with their daughter Ruby when her heart stopped and he battled to cope with grief in the aftermathShareCommentsBySteve Myall:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsVicki and Bruce discovered Ruby had died at  weeks "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad who was filmed with his partner as she gave birth to their stillborn child has spoken about how he struggled to cope with the trauma of the loss. Bruce Wagstaffs partner Vicki Beckett was  weeks pregnant with their daughter Ruby when the unborn babys heart stopped. Heartbroken the -year-olds were sent home from the hospital and told tothe next day so Vicki could be induced and give birth to the baby. A TV documentary team making a programme about still birth were in the hospital and Vicki and Bruce agreed to let them film the birth.  The result is heartbreaking footage showing tearful Bruce and his partner delivering Ruby which will screen on TV tonight. Bruce told the Mirror: It was a Monday morning and we went in for scan but the midwe couldnt find the heartbeat. She called in a colleague for a second opinion but I could tell by her face it wasnt good. In  seconds my le changed forever. Tonight Channel  viewers will see Bruce after seeing his we go through  hours of labour unable to bring himself to cut the umbilical cord - which had planned to do had she lived. He said: It was a blur. We went home and then realised we had to call people and in may ways thats the hardest point. You hear a voice and dont know what to say, I just said shes gone, Rubys gone. It was massive shock.  When it came to cut the cord, I couldnt do it, I wanted to run out of the room. I just broke down, Vicki was so strong. However he did hold his baby adding: For  seconds I held her and it felt like she was really there. Following the birth Bruce struggled to be around his partner. He said: I couldnt face it. Her boobs were hurting because her body was producing milk but there was no baby to drink it. Her arms were aching because her body was telling her to hold her child. People forget a womans body has spent nine months preparing for birth, it doesnt just stop. After the birth it wasnt long before the grief became impossible for Bruce to bear, he explained: I thought I was a strong man and could deal with but I couldnt I wanted to get back to normal as soon as I could and couldnt be around Vicki who was grieving more openly.  After ten days we started to go our separate ways and then I went to see a counsellor which I am so glad I did. Bruce said: I went to see my brother in Spain and was just walking down the street when the anxiety hit me and I thought I was having a heart attack. It was the grief. I was so naive. Happily the couple reconciled and along with two other couples feature in Child of Mine on Channel . Make sure you never miss an episode of the First Time Dads podcast.Subscribe on iTunes Subscribe on Acast Subscribe on SpotyWherever youre subscribing, add a rating and review to let us know what you think. Italy came top on .%, while the average across all  nations was .%. Oian cancer is the sixth most common cancer in women here, with , diagnosed every year – predicted to leap to , by . But the study found % of UK women were only diagnosed once the cancer had already spread.  Sue Rizzello, , from Berkshire, diagnosed in , said: “We need to act now so that more women know the symptoms, and so the system is set up to give more of us a fighting chance at an early diagnosis.” Symptoms are fairly general and include feeling full quickly, loss of appetite and tummy pain. title: grand designs host kevin mcclouds
story: NewsGrand Designs host Kevin McClouds advice on where you should NEVER buy a homeThe veteran TV presenter has issued this stern warning to prospective house buyers looking in these at-risk locationsShareCommentsByNeil Murphy:,  OCT NewsKevin McCloud has warned prospective buyers looking in these areas "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTV presenter Kevin McCloud has developed a well-earned reputation for being an expert on all housing related matters. The Grand Designs host has seen his fair share of building mishaps and developed a rock-solid understanding of when and where problems arise. Now the architecture critic has advised prospective house buyers on where they should NEVER buy a home.He told the Express : “I would strongly advise against buying on a floodplain unless your house is specically built to mitigate that.” A floodplain is a low-lying area of land near a river or stream. Homes in these vulnerable locations could be severely damagedthere is flooding resulting from heavy rainfall. The legendary critic has also told house hunters to narrow their search to properties that are energy efficient. He said: “I would strongly advise to be looking for houses which are green, which have low to zero energy bills. “It’s great financial resilience in your le and on a community-wide level it’s resilience to climate change.”  Kevin also revealed his interest in environmentally-friendly design which he hopes to promote He said: “When I invest I invest in renewable and ethical portfolios. “They may at the moment be yielding on par with conventional non-ethical investment but my belief is that in the future as the effects of global warning and climate change become more obvious to us all, these investments will start to make real sense and the same goes for a house. “Why would you spend more on a house that costs you pound, a year to heat  It’s just a waste of money.”

title: look inside 1930s house thats
story: NewsHave a look inside the s house that’s been frozen in timeThe detached home near Llanelli was built in  and very little inside has changed since, even most of the furniture are original pieces from the eraShareCommentsByJoanne RidoutKelly-Ann Mills:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe art deco house in Wales "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn iconic art deco home has gone on sale in Wales, and nothing has changed for years. The detached home was built in  and very little inside has changed since, even most of the furniture are original pieces from the era.The keys to this distinct home in Cross Hands near Llanelli , called Heol Bryngwili, was handed to the first owners in the autumn of .And its remained in the same family until now. The current owners are reluctantly passing the keys on as they need to downsize, reports Wales Online. Even just walking up to the property you get a sense of the unique and historic home that awaits you. The classic art deco features are obvious the led crittall windows and symmetrical feel to the design, yet broken up by a curved wall and window and the inclusion of a first floor balcony. Once the outside is painted white, the home will look more Miami Beach than Cross Hands... Originally the house may have had a flat roof in the art deco style, but the pitched roof is definitely a bonus, avoiding any possible flat roof problems in the future. In through the glass led front door and the hall still has all the original woodwork, including a brilliant built-in telephone seating and storage area.The stair rail, wood block flooring and door pelmet all promote the classic dark wood interior design look of the era. Deep coving and skirting boards, and solid wood led interior doors throughout the home add to the s visual display. Into the front reception room and one of the stand-out features are the two crittall windows. Multi-led and including a leaded classic arrow design in one , these windows are an absolute must-have in an authentic art deco home. Over the windows are decorative window pelmets incorporating the classic stepped art deco design. This attention to detail illustrates how important the design of the home was to the builder and the family who then owned it. The feature tiled fireplace with accent black horizontal tiling is straight out of a s design book and has surely been the main gathering point for the family and visitors through the decades. The arched alcove above the fireplace again shows that art deco design was, and still is, an important aspect of this home.  As was common decades ago, this front room would have probably been considered as the parlour, the posh room reserved for visitors and important family gatherings. The most used room by all family members would most likely have been the rear sitting room. In this family room the atmosphere is more relaxed. The room still has the crittall windows, pelmets and decorative coving but the fireplace is arguably less flamboyant than the front room and the built-in cupboards suggest a multi-ing family room with the need for storage and bookshelves. This warm and cosy room still emanates the atmosphere of yesteryear and the le of a busy family using the space. Decades ago this room would have been the heart-of-the-home, not the kitchen diner as it is today.Updated during the s the kitchen in this house is small by todays standards. Although perfectly usable, there is scope for a new owner to create a spacious kitchen diner at the rear of the property by getting the sledgehammer out.There are a number of small rooms behind the kitchen that could be incorporated into the space and luckily few art deco features remain here to destroy. Theres a boiler room, side entrance hallway and pantry that could all become part of a modern kitchen diner. Hopefully the new owner will chose the kitchen design carefully to complement and pay homage to the art deco calibre of the home, rather than overwhelming it with contemporary design. Upstairs there are three good sized bedrooms, with the master at the front of the house having direct access on to the curved balcony.  But the star of the show on the first floor is undoubtedly the bathroom. The original green tiling including horizontal dark accent tiles is a s site to behold. It is rare to find a bathroom with tiling untouched by time. The bath may have been replaced at some point, its likely the original was a roll-top bath, but many other features remain. The arched canopy over the bath is a delight, as is the window pelmet, ceiling coving and s style basin and taps. The toilet is in a separate room next to the main bathroom, resulting in the main room feeling spacious. Outside there is a rear garden which could be considered large for a suburban property, plus a lawned area at the side. There is a garage and workshop at the back of the land. This frozen in time property has always been owned by the same family and ideally the vendors are looking for a buyer that will love the original art deco features and s style as much as they have. Theres even the possibility of some of the original furniture being included in the sale by negotiation. This truly unique property offers a new owner a choice to preserve all the originality that makes it a one-off home of distinction. It remains to be seen how much of it is loved and restored and what ends up in a skip outside. The house is on the market for pound, with estate agent Clee Tompkinson Francis Carmarthen branch.

story: NewsWhy Meghan Markle and Prince Harry wont have full legal custody of their babyPrince William and Kate Middleton dont have custody of Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis eitherShareCommentsByKelly-Ann MillsCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video could-baby-influenced-harrys-choice-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Parents-to-be Prince Harry and Meghan Markle wont have custody of their baby when it arrives next Spring, due to a long-standing law. According to a royal expert, even second-in-line to the thrown Prince William and we Kate Middleton dont legally have full custody of their three children - Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis. This is because the family has an agreement with the Queen , which means she is granted full legal custody over all minor royals. Royal expert Marlene Koenig explained the rule to the Sun Online .She said: The sovereign has legal custody of the minor grandchildren.  Legislation passed during the reign of George I. It was known as The Grand Opinion for the Prerogative Concerning the Royal Family and it was about the King’s control over the education, the raising and the marriage of his grandchildren. He did it because he had a very poor relationship with his son, the future King George II, so they had this law passed that meant the King wasof his grandchildren. The law dates back more than  years to , a time when the monarchs right of supervision extended to his grandchildren and this right of right belongs to His Majesty, King of the Realm, even during their father’s letime. The Queen also had full custody of William and Harry when they were younger.This fact first came to light when Prince Charles and Princess Diana got orced in . In the couples orce agreement there was no mention of custody arrangements for the children, despite arrangements being made. This was because neither parent had full custody, instead this belonged to the Queen. This meant Charles and Diana had to get the Queens permission before doing simple things with their children, such as going on holiday. Marlene confirmed that the rule still exists today and technically the parents need the Queens permission to take their children out of the country. She added that despite this, the Queen is respectful of the wishes of the parents and wouldnt push her views upon them.

story: NewsPregnant mum living in one-bed flat with husband and two teenage children says she is in crisisBeth Dance said her Plymouth home was adequate until April, but since then her two teenage children have moved back in and she discovered she is pregnantShareCommentsByCarl Eve:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video pregnant-mum-living-one-bed-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pregnant mum whose two teenage children moved back in has shared the cramped condition shes living in as she fears for her family. Anxious Beth Dance says she is now in crisis and needs a bigger home.The -year-old told Plymouth Live that her one bedroom property was adequate for her and husband Martin until April this year.But after her -year-old son Zac moved back in from living with her ex-husband in Exeter, it has been increasingly cramped. And in May she found she was pregnant. Last month -year-old daughter Chloe – who had also been living with her father in Exeter – unexpectedly appeared on Beth’s front door following disagreements with his current partner.  Beth said she had gone to the authorities for help, bidding on homes through Devon Home Choice as each additional child appeared, hoping to get first a two-bedroom flat, then a three-bedroom and perhaps even a four-bedroom. However, complications arose quickly, thanks to her own past, her husband’s past and the process itself. Beth explained how she would be allowed to bid on up to three properties, but had to wait for a suitable place to appear on the website. When a bid was put in, she would be “gridlocked” from bidding with new places, waiting for up to five weeks to learnthe bid was accepted or whether she was considered suitable for the property.  She explained how properties which are marked “sensitive lets” mean certain people cannot have them, but Beth claims some of the properties are not marked as such and she has repeatedly bid for these properties only to later be turned down on the basis that she is an unsuitable tenant. Beth said she accepts that Martins criminal record has become a factor, with him coming out of prison in March following a theft conviction. However, she points out they have been together for seven years, while she accepts Martin is a recovering drug addict. For her own part, due to a dficult period when she was living in Exmouth, she admits she “lost the plot” and was charged for criminal damage, having targeted her neighbours’ cars.  It resulted in her moving to Plymouth in the hope of the pair starting over. She said: “We decided to downsize from our four-bedroom place in Exmouth to a one-bedroom flat in Plymouth. We were adequately housed and then things changed. “We are now in crisis. “The children are sleeping on the floor in the living room on mattresses and we have to pull them into the room from our bedroom each night, then drag them back again in the morning. “Martin has COPD and we need a place that has gas-central heating. “I can’t even buy a cot for the baby because there’s nowhere to put it. “We’ve been told we may be waiting month months and I give birth in December. “All we need is a three bedroom place, or at least a two bedroom.  “I’m just getting turned down and turned down for properties.” “Devon Home Choice often advertise it wrong, saying it’s for anyone but then after you apply there are restrictions on who can take up the place. “One time we wasted five weeks of bidding for a property. “We were offered a place in Torquay but because of our circumstances we were later refused. “We keep having to go back to the drawing board. “We’re all boxed up and have been for months, we’re living out of boxes, ready to go when we finally get approval for a bigger place. “We’ve gone to Plymouth City Council but they couldn’t help. “It’s just a waiting game.”  Beth said she has even gone to MP Luke Pollard and her local councillor for help. She added: “I know people will say why have a baby but our circumstances changed by me taking in our other children. “If that hadn’t of happened then a move to a two bedroom would have been adequate. “I haven’t got the money to go private because I just done have the funds. “We’re trapped in this situation and I just want someone, anyone, to listen to me. Its just not fair on the children. They havent done anything wrong. ” Beth said she was able to get Zac – who originally went to an Exmouth school – into a new school in Plymouth, but is still struggling to get Chloe into any school. Beth said: “She’s been told she has to catch up on subjects she’s never even done before. “It’s all been a nightmare”. Steve Ford, PCH Head of Neighbourhoods, said: We have sympathy for Miss Dances situation and have explained Devon Home Choices banding and allocation process to her. Miss Dances situation highlights the lack of suitable affordable housing in Plymouth. This is something we are trying to address with our numerous developments around the city. We are continually seeking and acquiring sites to meet this demand so that we can help people in Miss Dances position.

story: NewsPrincess Dianas former butler urges Prince Harry to be brave and name baby after his mumPaul Burrell has congratulated the royal couple on their baby news and suggested a name for their future childShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsPaul Burrell and Princess Diana in  visiting Sarajevo, Bosnia "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOn Monday morning, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex announced they were expecting their first child. Im sure Diana would be proud no matter what they name their child. Its not about being brave. Shes left her own legacy in her boys. story: NewsPrincess Diana used to play hilarious pranks on strangers before joining royal familyPrincess Diana used to put on funny voices and call people with amusing names in the phone book, according to royal biographerShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  OCT NewsDiana used to get up to all sorts of mischief "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIts no secret that Princess Diana had a mischievous side to her.She once told Prince Harry that he could be as naughty as he likes - as long as he doesnt get caught.And it turns out that she had a very rebellious streak when she was a young woman, and would even prank call people with silly names who appeared in the phone directory, according to royal biographer Andrew Morton. Before she married Charles in , Diana lived in an incredible flat in London with three of her best pals - where she had great fun.  In a  interview with Andrew Morton, Princess Diana described her days living in the fancy Knightsbridge flat as juvenile, innocent, uncomplicated and above all fun. She used to get up to all sorts of mischief with her school pal Carolyn Bartholomew, who lived in the flat with her. According to Mortons biography Diana: In Her Own Words, the naughty pair would take part in juvenile japes that involved ringing people with silly names who appeared in the telephone directory. Another of the playful duos favourite pastimes was ringing doorbells in the dead of night and planning raids of the ious apartments and cars owned by friends in the local area.  The apple doesnt fall far from the tree, as her children Harry and William seem to have inherited her fun, playful nature.In last years ITV documentary Diana, Our Mother: Her Le And Legacy, Harry reminisced about what a fun mum she was .He said: She would come and watch us play football and smuggle sweets into our socks. Behind closed doors she was a very loving caring mother, and an incredibly funny person. A total kid, through and through.

story: NewsTeen driver, , repeatedly runs over two women after using his car as weapon outside nightclub in shocking CCTVMcCauley Cox, , is facing jail after leaving two women with serious injuries after driving into a crowd outsidthe Courtyard club in NewportShareCommentsByAdam Hale:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video teenage-driver-uses-car-weapon-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShocking footage shows the moment a teenager ploughed into revellers outside a nightclub, leaving two women seriously injured. McCauley Cox, , was today found guilty of two counts of grievous bodily harm with intent after jurors heard he drove into a crowd after a fight broke out. Both women suffered serious injuries, Newport Crown Court was told, and Cox was warned he faces a tough sentence. Cox was previously convicted after leading police on a high-speed chase on the M and crashed through a barrier on the Severn Bridge. Judge Daniel Williams told Cox he would adjourn his sentencing until Friday morning, adding: You face a substantial sentence in a young offenders institute.  CCTV used in the trial shows Coxs car approaching a crowd of pedestrians outside the Courtyard nightclub on Cambrian Road, Newport, as some begin fighting in the early hours of April . The car clips one of the pedestrians, leading some to kick the Ford C-Max people carrier and confront Cox at either side of his vehicle. Moments later, the car darts forward and turns on to the pavement towards a group of people, including victims Sophie Poole and Emma Nicholls, who are sitting on a kerb.  Cox runs over the two girls before reversing back over them, then darting forward once more over their bodies and reversing further down the street. Witnesses begin to attack his car and smash its windscreen, prompting Cox to accelerate out of the road at speed, missing other pedestrians by inches. Police found the car nearby later that day having been set on fire.  Prosecutor James Wilson accused Cox of using his vehicle to deliberately run over a man who was trading blows with his friend, only to miss and repeatedly run over the two young women, who are in their early twenties. Mr Wilson said: You were using the car as a weapon. You know full well the reason you went for that man is because he was confronting a friend of yours. You deliberately drove that car at that man with intent to cause him very serious harm. And you are responsible for those girls injuries because of your anger and annoyance at that man who was confronting your friend. Witness Nathan Rumble said Cox hit the two girls like a speed bump, and said it appeared the driver intentionally drove his car into the crowd.  Mr Rumble said: It was wrong. He was going for them. You cant just hit someone twice and not know what you are doing. The two girls, who are friends from university, suffered really serious injuries after being repeatedly run over, with Miss Poole needing specialist skin grafts and Miss Nicholls suffering a lacerated spleen. Cox, from John Ireland Close, Newport, was remanded in custody. After the verdict, Kelly Huggins of the CPS, said: McCauley Cox used his vehicle as a weapon and caused an incident which left his victims with serious injuries. The CPS showed in court that his actions in driving his car into the crowd and reversing over those injured on two occasions amounted to this serious offence.Evidence included CCTV footage showing the incident and its aftermath where Cox showed no regard for those he had injured.Our thoughts are with the victims as they recover from their injuries.

Forecasters have said a substantial amount of snow is expected towards the end of the month. And a snowy Halloween is thought to be likely, some forecasters say. Exacta Weather forecaster James Madden told the Daily Star : Temperatures will drop and the risk of snow will rise considerably towards the end of this month and into the start of November. There is a chance we could see blizzards developing over higher ground particularly in northern parts of the country. Even parts of central and southern England may be at risk of some wintry weather during the final part of this month although here it is not expected to be as signicant.  Scotland will get the heaviest snowfall this month, WeatherAction forecaster Piers Corbyn claimed. And its time to layer up as temperatures will plunge below zero as early as next week. Some forecasters say November will likely be colder than usual and snow or snow showers arent out of the question in many places. Britons woke up to frost and fog in many places today as temperatures dropped to -C, with the morning mist particularly heavy in parts of East Anglia. Katesbridge in Co Down, Northern Ireland, was one of the coldest spots at -C. It was one of the coldest temperatures of the season so far, and its a sign of things to come next week and next month. High pressure is set to bring in colder air from the north, making snow a possibility over especially in the north east.  WeatherAction says Britain could be gripped by freezing temperatures for four months due to a polar vortex and could get so low they could break records in October. However, the Met Office believes there is unlikely to be snow in England in October, though there may be overnight frosts. A Met Office spokesperson told Bristol Live : There is, as always at this time of year, a chance there may be some snow over high ground in Scotland and to lower levels in the far north of Scotland. Snow is regularly seen over higher ground in Scotland from September onwards. However, as far as the chance of snow in [the south of England] in October is concerned for the rest of the month the weather looks fairly typical for the time of year. It is likely to stay generally dry and bright in the south interspersed with spells of more wet and windy weather. Temperatures ying around average, but becoming colder as we go through the month with an increasing risk of overnight frosts and fog. On the whole temperatures are likely to be rather cold, but some brief milder spells are also possible.

story: NewsWoman reveals horror of watching screaming sister and mum shot dead in front of herHeavily-pregnant Raven Whitbread, , told a jury she witnessed her family gunned down from just feet away at their home in St Leonards, East SussexShareByMark Reynolds:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsVictims Michelle Savageand mum Heather Whitbread"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman told a jury yesterday how she watched horror-struck as her sister and mother were shot dead just feet from her. Raven’s mum Heather Whitbread, , handed her two of their dogs and urged her to flee. Raven said: “I was looking down and then I heard my mum shout ‘don’t you dare’. story: NewsBride-to-be calls off dream wedding at last minute and donates £.k venue to couple shes never metUniversity student Kolbie Sanders turned heartbreak into generosity by offering up her wedding venue to strangersShareCommentsByIsolde WaltersChris kitching:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsKolbie Sanders and her former fiance Skylar Cotton in happier times "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA bride-to-be called off her engagement a week before the big day and donated her dream wedding venue to a couple she had never met. The -year-old university student wrote on Facebook that she had just  hours to find a couple prepared to get married at the wedding venue. She was inundated with messages from hundreds of husbands and brides-to-be desperate to win her big day.  After whittling down the applicants to a shortlist of , Kolbie, from Lindale in Texas, US, plucked lucky winner Halie Hipsher, , out of a hat. The mother of seven-month-old Riley will wed Matthew Jones, , an oil field worker, at the Belle Vue wedding venue in Tyler, Texas, this Saturday. And touchingly, Kolbie will be guest of honour. Kolbie, a student at the University of Texas at Tyler, called off her own wedding to Skylar, , an oil well worker, when she realised the passion had left their relationship. Her generosity was soon matched by a local photographer, caterer, florist, hair stylist and makeup artist who offered their services to the winning couple. story: NewsTerried couple photobombed by ghost of Titanics captain in historic pub linked to famous shipThe couple noticed something blurry in the background of their picture - and say they felt something cold on their backs when it was takenShareCommentsByAliki Kraterou:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsCheryl,  and Luke Arkless,  with the ghost in the background behind Cheryl "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A couple were left terried after what they believe is the ghost of the Titanics captain photobombed them in a historic pub with connections to the doomed ship.Cheryl and Luke Arkless noticed something blurry in the background of their photo, taken in a bar which is full to the brim with original memorabilia from the infamous voyage. They said they also felt something cold on their backs. The couple, both , were on a trip to Belfast in Northern Ireland when they visited the city’s Robinsons pub. But after the pair, from Devon, snapped a romantic shot together they were horried to spot a spooky face right behind them. And they believe it bears a great resemblance to the ship’s captain, Edward John Smith.  Cake maker Cheryl, a mum-of-two, said: “My mother in law took three photos of my husband and I, all of them within seconds. “It was a bit cold at our backs, but we didn’t see or feel anyone behind us. “It was only when we flew back to England and when I was looking at the photos that I noticed something blurry. “I called my husband and he said it was probably a person walking behind us very fast. “But the thing is, everything around us is crystal clear apart from that blur. “I was very skeptical at first but now I really think it looks like a man. “There is a strong ‘Titanic’ background in the bar, and the more you look at the more he resembles the captain. “On the right hand side behind us a band was playing, so he looks ashe is watching the band.”  Cheryl and Luke visited Belfast with Luke’s parents over the summer and had met some friends for a few drinks on July , when the picture was taken. The second bar they visited was the Robinsons, a pub famous for its Titanic vibe as it features items recovered from the wreckage including letters and postcards written on board, first and second class china used on all White Star Line vessels and a Philomena doll. The image has just been released for the first time after Cheryl enlisted the help of ghost-hunting group Paranormal Investigations UK, who analysed the picture and ran a series of tests to confirm it was genuine.  Cheryl added: “I was intrigued, I simply wanted some answers. “When I got the report back from Paranormal Investigations UK I was freaked out, as they said the picture was  per cent unexplained. “I was left with more questions than answers. “I phoned Robinsons to tell them what happened, but they said nothing like it had been reported before. “My children were fascinated – I showed them the photo and explained to them that whatever is in that photo is not meant to be there and then we all watched ‘Titanic’ together- they didn’t know what it was or that it was a real ship. “After watching the film, my daughter Yasmin pointed out the face in the picture saying ‘look mum, it’s the Captain’. “I literally got goosebumps, because I had not told them anything about it looking like the captain. “I was excited and creeped out at the same time – she is adamant is the captain in the picture.

title: first flesh eating fish 150
story: NewsFossil of first flesh-eating fish with razor-sharp teeth that evolved into piranha discoveredScientists say the "remarkable" bony fish found in Germany lived in the sea at the same time as the dinosaurs roamed the earthShareCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe fish is believed to be the earliest known flesh-eater "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe earliest known flesh-eating fish - thought to be  million years old - has been discovered in a German quarry. The fossilised remains of the prianha-like fish has sharp teeth it used to attack other fish. Scientists say the remarkable bony fish lived in the sea at the same time as the dinosaurs roamed the earth. They say they would bite off chunks of flesh from other fish. And researchers have even found the victims.  Other fish that had apparently been nibbled on, were found in the same limestone deposits in the quarry of Ettling in Germany. Study co-author Professor David Bellwood, of James Cook University in Australia, said: We have other fish from the same locality with chunks missing from their fins. This is an amazing parallel with modern piranhas, which feed predominantly not on flesh but the fins of other fishes. Its a remarkably smart move as fins regrow, a neat renewable resource. Feed on a fish and it is dead nibble its fins and you have food for the future. The fish, described in the journal Current Biology, is part of the renown collections at the Jura-Museum in Eichst tt.  It comes from the same limestone deposits that contained Archaeopteryx, a transitional fossil between dinosaurs and modern birds. The international research team said that the tooth pattern and shape, jaw morphology, and mechanics suggest a mouth equipped to slice flesh or fins. Thay say the evidence points to the possibility that the early piranha-like fish may have exploited aggressive mimicry in a striking parallel to the feeding patterns of modern piranha. Study co-author Dr Martina K lbl-Ebert, drector of Jura-Museum Eichst tt, said: We were stunned that this fish had piranha-like teeth. It comes from a group of fishes, the pycnodontids, that are famous for their crushing teeth. It is like finding a sheep with a snarl like a wolf. But what was even more remarkable is that it was from the Jurassic. Fish as we know them, bony fishes, just did not bite flesh of other fishes at that time.  Sharks have been able to bite out chunks of flesh but throughout history bony fishes have either fed on invertebrates or largely swallowed their prey whole. Biting chunks of flesh or fins was something that came much later. Prof Bellwood said: The new finding represents the earliest record of a bony fish that bit bits off other fishes, and whats more it was doing it in the sea. So when dinosaurs were walking the earth and small dinosaurs were trying to fly with the pterosaurs, fish were swimming around their feet tearing the fins or flesh off each other. The researchers described the new find a staggering example of evolutionary versatility and opportunism.

title: jamal khashoggi saudi journalists haunting
story: NewsSaudi journalist Jamal Khashoggis haunting final instruction to fiancée before being butchered alive by hit squadMr Khashoggi, , gave his fiancée Hatice Cengiz a clear instruction before entering the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, Turkey,  days agoShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news article.ece,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Missing Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi gave his fianceacutee a haunting final instruction before stepping inside the consulate where he vanished.Mr Khashoggi, , a critic of the Saudi leadership, was filmed on CCTV arriving at the countrys consulate in Istanbul, Turkey, on October . He has not been seen since entering the building - with reports claiming he was butchered alive by a -strong hit squad who tore his fingers off. Audio footage allegedly captured his agonised screams as his killers spent seven minutes murdering him and dismembering his body with a bone saw. On the day he vanished, a cheerful Mr Khashoggi had travelled to the consulate with his Turkish fianceacutee, Hatice Cengiz, who waited outside.  And despite having no foreboding of what was to come, he gave his partner a clear instruction before going inside the building.He told me to alert the Turkish authoritiesI did not hear from him soon, Hatice wrote in a New York Times opinion piece at the weekend.Had I known it would be the last time I would see Jamal, I would have rather entered the Saudi consulate myself. The rest is history: He never walked out of that building. And with him, I also got lost there. Mr Khashoggi, a US resident, had been visiting the consulate to obtain marriage documents that would enable him to wed his fianceacutee.  He was cheerful the morning we were going to the Saudi consulate to get a document certying his orce, explained Hatice. She added that she decided to skip university and travel to the consulate with her partner, who had been told to be there at pm. During their journey, the couple discussed their plans for the rest of the day, including having dinner with their friends and family. However, they would never make the dinner - for Mr Khashoggi never emerged from the consulate, according to his fianceacutee. Since his disappearance - which has made headlines across the world - Hatice has found herself questioning whether he is still alive.  In the opinion piece, published on Saturday, she said she had found herself thinking that Jamal and I are no longer in the same world. Turkish officials have said they have recorded evidence that Mr Khashoggi was assassinated by hitmen who flew in on a private jet.They believe his body was then removed - with one Turkish source claiming the journalist was chopped up on a table while still alive.However, the Saudis have strongly denied the allegations, insisting that he left the consulate safely on the day he was last seen. This week, a Turkish pro-government newspaper published details from audio recordings purportedly documenting Mr Khashoggis murder.  Yeni Safak reported that his torturers severed his fingers during an interrogation, and that the journalist was killed within minutes. According to the report, he was later beheaded and dismembered. Yesterday, a New York Times report cited a senior Turkish official confirming the details published by Yeni Safak. It has been claimed that members of the alleged hit squad listened to music through earphones as they dismembered their victim.A Turkish source, who has allegedly listened to an audio clip of the incident, earlier told Middle East Eye : They had come to kill him. Mr Khashoggi was said to have been dragged from the Consul Generals office into his study next door, where he was dumped on a table. Loud screams could then be heard - which only stopped when he was injected with an unknown substance, according to the source. Moments later, his body was allegedly cut up - while he was still alive.Earlier, a source told Sky News that one line of inquiry is that a very fast-acting chemical acid was then used to dissolve the journalists body parts.Turkey has said there are  suspects in the case - allegedly including forensic evidence expert Salah Muhammad al-Tubaigy, dubbed Dr Death. The MEE source claimed that Tubaigy listened to music via earphones as he cut up the reporters body while he was still breathing. He allegedly advised his accomplices to do the same.  When I do this job, I listen to music. You should do [that] too, Tubaigy could be heard saying in the recording, the source said. According to Yeni Safak, Mr Khashoggi was told to shut up at one point during his ordeal, which also allegedly saw his head cut. Earlier this week, another suspect in the Turkish police probe into the case was confirmed as Maher Abdulaziz Mutreb, a Saudi diplomat. It is thought Mutreb may have worked as a bodyguard for Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman, whom he travelled extensively with.He used to work as a diplomat at the Saudi Embassy in London, according to the New York Times , which said several other suspects have been linked by witnesses and records to Bin Salmans security detail. The newspaper stated that at least nine of the suspects worked for the Saudi security services, military or other government ministries. It is alleged they flew out the same day as the killing, and brought a bone saw with them for the purpose of cutting up Mr Khashoggis body. Records allegedly show that two private jets chartered by a Saudi firm arrived and departed from Istanbul on October . Mr Khashoggi has so far been missing for  days. The Washington Post columnist was critical of the Saudi government, calling for reforms. He had worked at the Saudi embassies in Washington, US, and London, and was well-liked by both fellow journalists and diplomats. He was described by one as a warm and funny man. According to Dexter Filkins, writing for The New Yorker , the journalist was also loyal to his principles and refused to compromise his values.This prompted the Saudi government, in , to silence him, claims Dexter, adding that Mr Khashoggi fled to the US last year. Yesterday, US President Donald Trump said he did not want to abandon close ally Saudi Arabia over the journalists disappearance, and he needed to see evidence to prove Turkish claims he was killed by Saudi agents. Mr Trump said he was waiting for a full report on what had happened to Mr Khashoggi from Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, whom he has sent to Saudia Arabia and Turkey to meet with officials over the incident. This is despite US lawmakers having pointed the finger at the Saudi leadership and mounting Western pressure on Riyadh to provide answers. Last Saturday, a Turkish newspaper reported that recordings made on Mr Khashoggis Apple Watch - had been uncovered by investigators.  These recordings allegedly indicated he was tortured and killed, but the report in the Sabah daily could not immediately be veried. “The moments when Khashoggi was interrogated, tortured and murdered were recorded in the Apple Watch’s memory,” the paper said. It added that the watch had synched with the journalists iPhone, which Hatice was said to be carrying outside the consulate. But tech experts say it is highly unlikely the watch could have recorded actions inside the embassy and uploaded them to an iCloud account. Mr Khashoggis disappearance has provoked an international outcry against Saudi Arabia, the worlds top oil exporter.
